caption:
Tag your green balls!  Those people who get to be part of your inner circle. The ones you feel safe to be yourself with. The ones you can share your best and most vulnerable moments with. These people that we connect with deeply are essential to our health and longevity. Good quality relationships show up in the research as the most powerful predictor of a long, healthy and happy life. But they are not the only people we need in our lives. There are many people that play a meaningful role in our lives (as we do in theirs) without ever developing a deep and personal connection. I think recognising the value in the diverse relationships that we encounter is one way to appreciate that each offers us something to learn from and feel grateful for. The aim is not to be left with just the people in that inner circle, but to use boundaries effectively so that we can safely experience a variety of relationships. What are your thoughts on this? 

?? Feel free to share. More videos @drjulie

When we feel painful emotion the most natural human response is to pull away, escape them and avoid. We block them out with anything that feels safe and pleasurable. But when we do that, the painful emotions don’t always disappear forever. We find ourselves trapped in cycles of addictive behaviours that keep the emotion at bay for just a short time. 

The way we guide people to process painful emotion in therapy is to allow the emotion to be there, turn towards it and feel it, while soothing yourself through the process with skills that help you to tolerate the distress. This enables the emotion to take its natural course and wash over you. Emotions come in waves so we know they will increase in intensity, peak and then come back down again.

Who else does this ? Does it happen more with certain people and less with others? Or maybe it happens more when the choice is one that enables you to hold your own needs as equal to others. 

That need we feel to justify ourselves and offer up detailed explanations can be seen as a safety behaviour. An action that helps to bring down the fear associated with holding a boundary. It works temporarily but, in the long term, leads to an increased need to do the same. We find ourselves trapped and unable to hold a boundary if we feel we can’t avoid the disapproval of others.

Maybe asserting yourself in the past led to rejection, abandonment or a complete override of your own needs. Maybe love was conditional. Or maybe it was considered your responsibility to ensure that others remained happy. However the cycle began, it can be broken. It takes time and practise. And it always starts with awareness. So start looking out for those times when you hold a boundary and immediately follow it up with over-explaining and justifying yourself to others.

Don’t wait to feel confident before starting. It won’t arrive spontaneously.TIPS FOR BUILDING CONFIDENCE BELOW: 
• Action builds confidence over time. 
• Rather than big, one-off actions, go for consistency over intensity. Repetition that you can sustain is crucial for building confidence.
• You don’t have to overwhelm yourself. Start small and manageable in the stretch zone where you make most progress with performance. 

The model in this video is adapted from Karl Rohnke’s Comfort, Stretch and Panic model, which was developed based on the Yerkes-Dodson law. This law posits that peak performance happens when people experience a moderate amount of pressure.

You might need to hear this today!
 Hands up on the comments who else tends to set a massive goal and then go all for a a week or two before fizzling out? If you do you’re not alone. I think we do this when we favour intensity over consistency. But if we can commit to a change that is small enough to persist at over time then the gains far exceed that short but intense burst. 

So when you want to make a change, focus less on what the results might be and when they will arrive. Instead focus on creating a process that feels easy enough to do consistently. Once it becomes a part of your everyday routine your brain is great at starting to automate some of that for you so that you don’t have to rely on motivation as much as when you started.

 The example of the plane in this video was inspired by James Clear who is another great translator of the research on habit change. Others include Charles Duhigg and BJ Fogg.

The last one is the most important! What else would you add to these? Share with me in the comments what you wish everybody understood about depression.

Nobody can know these things until they know, so these conversations about mental health are helping to squash some of the old misconceptions that were once widely held. Those misconceptions can hold people back in their own recovery. They can also hold people back from being able to support in the most effective way. 

Here are some more tips for how to support someone with their mental health:

* It’s ok if you don’t know how to talk about the painful stuff. You don’t have to be a therapist to be a great support. For example, distraction from your own distress by chatting with a friend can be just as helpful.
* If you are not sure what is the right thing to say, tell them. Let them know that you care about them and want to help, but have no idea how. Ask them what support would be most helpful to them right now.
* Try to help in ways that promote recovery rather than hinder it. For example, if your loved one is managing to cook for themselves, join them but don’t take over the activity. Taking a break from something can make it harder to go back to it. Instead, help like offering childcare while they go to therapy or a doctor makes working on recovery easier.

Wait for it  So many of us numb our emotion because the natural instinct is to push away anything painful or uncomfortable. You imagine that if you allow any of your emotions to surface, that they’ll all rise up and you’ll lose control of them, maybe even struggle to calm them again. This is a common fear that prevents many people from talking about how they feel or accessing therapy. But there is a misconception about how you work through trauma in therapy. A therapist will never ask you to bring up old wounds until they trust that you can manage those painful emotions safely. And one of the reasons that therapy takes time is that it’s not done all at once. Things are done at your own pace in a safe space and only when you both decide that you are ready.

No.2 is all too common  Which one hits home for you? In truth we all feel the strong urge to hide the things that make us feel most vulnerable. It feels like protection. But shame and loneliness thrives in the dark. That is why I am starting this conversation. When we share our stories and the very natural human coping mechanisms that we have, someone else speaks up and says, “Yep, me too.” Then shame and loneliness shrinks and connection builds. Keep an eye out for these 4. Which do you notice in your relationships? Is the other person using your emotions to get what they want? Emotional manipulation can be very subtle and hard to spot. But when it becomes pervasive some of the telltale signs can be feelings of confusion about how you keep overriding your own knowledge, instincts and values when making decsions. Increasing self-doubt and uncertainty in your own judgement leads you to give even more power to the other person. Once you start to notice when this is happening, there is opportunity for change. Starting to put in new boundaries with someone who has previously had full control in a relationship is not an easy process. So getting support from a trusted friend or therapist to help on that path is often a good idea. If anyone would like me to do a video on how to start holding boundaries, let me know in the comments.

(BTS in my stories) Here’s why eliminating stress is not the answer. Quite simply because it’s impossible. Just like that hose pipe, we can’t switch it off. Life will always find new challenges to throw our way. But the good news is that we don’t have to be at the mercy of it. There are lots of things we can learn that help us to bring down the intensity of the stress response, or to create a release valve that means we have more capacity to deal with things tomorrow.

The last sentence is something that so many people seem to resonate with. An ability to neglect or even completely disregard your own emotions while being highly sensitive to how everyone else is feeling around you. 

This often makes sense when you start to unravel the learning that occurred in early life when you were entirely dependent on the adults around you. But once we reach adulthood, that way of relating to people can make it more difficult to find personal fulfilment or to have healthy relationships. 

Do you notice this showing up in your own life? When does it happen? And what does it cost you? What price do you pay for only listening to the emotions of others?

This took a while 
One of the biggest mistakes people make when working on big change is underestimating the power of those small, consistent actions that embed us in a new way of living. If we can focus on the small, daily steps in the process, the results start to take care of themselves. And when we take on the new process as a part of our identity, it no longer takes the conscious effort and motivation that it needed when you first started. It’s just who you are now.

Motivation is tied to your identity 

We do things because we’ve always done them, and over time they become part of who you are. Think about all the things you just do naturally day to day. 

So, when we’re trying to build new habits, we need to see the thing as a part of who we are if we want it to feel like an easier lift. That’s when positive affirmations can come in. 

For example: you want to write a newsletter, but imposter syndrome is creeping in and you keep telling yourself no one wants to hear what you have to say. Well of course you’re not going to start. 

But if you tell yourself “I have tons of ideas and I’m actually super excited about becoming a better writer by pressing send every week”, you’re much more likely to form that new habit and build motivation. 

To listen to the full episode with @drjulie, search ‘Deep Dive with Ali Abdaal’ wherever you like to listen to your podcasts.

Here’s the low-down from a psychologist on why your thoughts seem to run away with you when you’re anxious and what you can do about it. When your threat response is triggered, you are in survival mode. When your brain senses that you might not be safe, speed is more important than accuracy. So your brain does a great job of anticipating threats and jumping to conclusions in order to keep you safe. This means your brain is not taking the time to consider all potential perspectives. It skips all that and takes a short cut to the ideas that could help keep you safe (if that is needed). This speed of processing and a focus on safety leads to bias. We can’t stop that bias. But we can take the power out of it by familiarising ourselves with the types of bias to look out for and naming those thought biases when we notice them. Then we can be open to considering alternative perspectives. Below are a few thought biases that come up with anxiety:

Personalising - this is when we take an ambiguous situation and assume it’s about us. E.g. my friend didn’t wave back. She must hate me.

Catastrophising - when your brain offers up the worst case scenario that hasn’t happened yet and plays it out for you like a movie on repeat, triggering more anxiety.

Spotlight effect - this when we overestimate how much other people are judging us negatively. Something we all do, but do more of when we are anxious.

This is one of the biggest misconceptions that causes many people to give up on their goals. We expect every day to be a little bit better than the last. So when we hit a hurdle and have a bad day or a bad week, we tell ourselves that we are back at square one and feel like giving up. But when we can expect tough days along the way and appreciate that they are a normal part of the process, we can focus our efforts on getting back on track, rather than wasting time trying to decide whether to quit or keep going.

Important to remember this.
Who else gets that rush of guilt when you have to say no or hold a boundary? Join the club! But that guilt might be more to do with learning earlier in life that the needs and feelings of others always trump your own. That is was your job to keep others happy. Sometimes guilt can tell us that we are not doing the right thing. But guilt is not a fact. Listen to it. Then make your decision  taking into account your needs too.

Can you relate? Does your world come crashing down around you, even with small mistakes? If you notice that happens, it’s a great opportunity to learn something important about yourself. Here’s some of the questions to ask yourself:
• What feelings have come up in reaction to this mistake?
• Were those feelings more intense than they might have been for others in this situation?
• What thoughts came up about me, or others, or the world?
• What urges came up? Maybe urges to escape, self-punish, or lash out at someone else? 
• What does this mistake mean to you? Do you believe it says something about who you are as a person? Look for those “I am” statements, such as “I am a failure” or “I am unloveable” 

Those statements that seem to get triggered and then cause intense pain, can often reflect some damaging core beliefs about ourselves or the world. We are not consciously aware of them all the time. But they rise up when we find even the slightest sign that they might be true, no matter how much evidence we have to the contrary. This is called confirmation bias. Shaking up core beliefs is highly psychologically threatening because it disrupts our ability to predict the world around us. So, even when a belief is not a healthy (or true) one, your brain will look to confirm it before letting it go.

Important reminder ??
More tips for coping with a breakup ??

• We don’t only grieve when people die. We grieve when relationships end and things change. We grieve for the loss of what we dreamt that relationship could be. We grieve for the aspects of that relationship that we miss, even if other parts of it were damaging. So let yourself grieve, without attaching the assumption that it means you should return to it.
• When you find yourself preoccupied with the other person’s behaviour after the breakup, remind yourself that you cannot control how others behave. You cannot allow your wellbeing to be determined by another. Take your life into your own hands and start working on constructing this new life in which you look after yourself, trusting that it was right for the relationship to end. 
• If you know the relationship was damaging but you find yourself looking back with rose tinted glasses, take action to ensure that you make informed choices. Not choices based on an idealised view of someone who couldn’t live up to that all the time. Write down and remind yourself of the clear reasons that you decided the relationship was not right for you.

Feel free to share with others @drjulie

Relatable?
Tips for people pleasers below 

• Balancing your own needs with those of others is not a sign of selfishness. It is a sign of emotional maturity. When we start to set boundaries, how we frame it in our minds is crucial to help us with the guilt feelings that often come up when we start making changes.
• If you notice that your identity is wrapped up in your care taking roles, this can make it even more difficult to make changes. It’s ok to still have that but there may be room to expand your sense of who you are to include other areas of your life and other skills that you have.
• If you are no longer sure what your own preferences are because you have always deferred to what others want, then it’s time to start experimenting with small decisions and reflecting on your own experiences. 
• Keep reminding yourself that it is possible to say no and still be a good person.

TOP TIPS FOR ANXIETY BELOW ?? 

• Anxiety is not bad and we can’t (and wouldn’t want to) eliminate it altogether. It is simply your body’s alarm system trying to keep you safe.
• The fear response naturally gives us the urge to avoid the feared situation. But avoidance is only the best outcome if the situation is truly dangerous. 
• We may feel anxiety simply because we are trying something new and the novel situation triggers the stress response. This is your brain allowing you to be alert because we don’t know how this situation goes.
• So when that alarm sounds in your body and mind, you get to decide whether you keep moving forward or you escape to safety.
• To live a full life alongside natural human anxiety we must base choices on our values. By this I mean, the kind of person you want to be, the contribution you want to make and what you want your actions to represent. 
• Getting clarity on your own personal values and what matter most to you is a brilliant way to make the best choices in the face of fear. I use it all the time. 

 For all the details on how to do this, you can follow the values check-in exercises in my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? Currently half price at £8. See link in my bio for hardback and audio book versions.

The last one I see most often. See below for what to do about it. ??

• Your attachment style is not your fault. These are the patterns of relating to our caregivers from the early years of our lives. But while they develop early in life, we don’t have to be at the mercy of them. 
• The first place to start is getting to know how your attachment style seems to impact on how you show up in your relationship today. Start keeping a journal. Pay attention to the times when you need connection, but seem unable to seek it out, or when you think your partner is making a bid for connection and you experience that as a threat.
• Share your discoveries with your partner. If they understand that you are working on this, they will be in a better place to support you in the way that you need them to.
• If intimacy feels threatening or uncomfortable, take your time. Talk to your partner about what small changes you would like to make.
• A couples therapist can be a great resource to help you work through this. There are no quick fixes, but time, effort and support can lead to changes for you and your relationships. 

For more on attachment styles, check out my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? See link in bio to get yours.

I see No.4 all the time. (This reel took a few goes )
We all get overworked and tired every now and then but burnout is more than tiredness. Burnout is when stress becomes chronic and has a detrimental effect on other areas in your life. 

Signs of burnout include chronic exhaustion alongside restlessness and trouble sleeping, poor self-care such as diet and exercise. Other signs include repeated emotional distress, such as anxiety, low mood, or anger outbursts. You may notice your performance at work is going down, while you feel you are working harder than ever, you may also start feeling disconnected with loved ones and struggle to get along as well as you normally do.
Below are some tips on how to prevent burnout but if you want more on this and how to make stress start working for you, see the link in my bio for my no.1 Sunday Times Bestseller, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? It’s currently half price (£8) in hardback and free when you sign up to Audible. 

A few tips on burnout:
 Start working out what you can say no to. Often we feel obliged to say yes to every request or opportunity. When our health is in question, it’s a pretty good reason to practice the art of saying no to things that are not an absolute priority.
 Prioritise self-care. Get back to basics because they are the foundations of good mental and physical health. Make sleep, healthy food, hydration, exercise and social time top of your to do list. And don’t underestimate the power of these things to build your resilience.
 Re-think what matters. We are vulnerable to burnout when we are working hard on something that is not in line with our own values. Instructions on this in my book. 
 Get support. If you are worried about your mental health in any way, seeking support from a trusted friend or a professional is key. Human connection is a powerful tool. Use it.

If your top priority has always been other people, then it can be incredibly hard to turn around that habit of a lifetime. So this is when it helps to find new ways to frame it in your mind. In an ideal world you would feel driven to look after yourself because you have love and respect for you. But if you do not feel that way yet, it’s ok to make it happen by recognising that looking after yourself helps you to be the best you can be for your loved ones.

For more details on how to build that, see the link in my bio for my book Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before?

TIPS BELOW FOR ANXIOUS ATTACHMENT STYLES

• If some of the points in this video sound familiar, it’s worth reading up on anxious attachment styles in more depth. 
• The first step is to build awareness of where these patterns came from and how they are affecting your adult relationships now.
• It is worth remembering that you didn’t choose this. But you also don’t have to be at the mercy of it. 
• The patterns helped you to feel safe as a child but are now outdated and tend to cause problems in adult relationships. So try not to be too hard on yourself when you follow the old patterns. They are hard cycles to break because they worked for many years. 

For more on attachment styles see the link in my bio for my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before?

When we hear of people who took their own life in response to bullying, we all see why #BeKind makes sense. But do we ever stop to think about whether we live by that, not only towards others, but to ourselves? 

If you had to endure bullying in your childhood, either in school or your own home, it is possible that you internalised the voice of those bullies as your own. This is not a mistake. It’s your own brain anticipating those responses before they happen so you can stay safe. But, now you are an adult, and hopefully in a safer environment, that self-criticism and self-attack no longer serves you in the same way. Instead, it will be holding you back by keeping you in a state of fight or flight. 

One way to start working on this is to document it. Start journalling about how you respond to yourself in both positive and negative situations. 

For more on how to take that further, see the link in my bio for my no.1 bestselling book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before?

No.6 is hard to spot. Do you notice any of these? When you’re worried about a friend, how do you start that conversation with them? Share your ideas in the comments so that others can do the same. The signs in this video are just a few of the many and varied changes you might notice in a friend. So any time you are concerned about them, let them know. Stay curious and non-judgemental. Ask open questions. Take time to really listen to the answers. It’s ok not to be the therapist. Simply being there for a friend can make all the difference in their recovery. Be willing to walk alongside them through their struggles and you will already be helping more than you know.

NEVER SAY NO.1 
See below for what to say instead ??

• “People will forget what you said…but will never forget how you made them feel.” - Maya Angelo. This quote rings true when you are trying to support someone who is struggling. Focus less on getting the exact words right, and more on how you are trying to make them feel. 
• Aim to make them feel safe, secure, respected, and listened to, really listened to.
• Park any judgement that arises and turn your mind to curiosity. Seek only to understand. 
• Ask about when things feel better, when they feel worse, what helps, and what makes it more difficult. As you build a detailed picture of what it is like for them, they will also benefit from the insight gained by reflecting on it in this way.
• Ask them how you can best support them. Take the guessing game out of it. Many people already have a clear idea of what would help them. It can be as simple as consistently showing up to be a friend.
• Remember, you are not here to solve all their problems. Don’t underestimate the power of simply being there and showing you care.
• You can help in practical ways, like babysitting while they attend therapy appointments or joining them to go out for a walk every day. Try to support them in things that will steer toward recovery.

Which one resonated for you the most? These are just a few of the factors that can lead to procrastination. For anyone looking for tips on how to overcome it so that you can get on with the things that matter to you, I’ve included a few points below. 

Points for tackling procrastination:

•Turn from the self-criticism to curiosity. So rather than get hard on yourself for it, ask yourself why it might be happening and be ready to get honest with yourself.

•If a task feels overwhelming, don’t expect yourself to do it all at once. Break it down into tiny steps that don’t feel so daunting.

•Start your day with the hardest task first. Minimise the time you have to talk yourself out of it, if that is what you do.

•Start questioning your relationship with failure. Perfectionism makes us afraid to fail which can create a block to progress and risk taking. Learning about growth mindset can help this.

• Get really honest with yourself about whether the goal is your own or someone else’s. Keep connected to why you are working toward this thing to help you over the hump of not feeling like it.

For more, check out my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? See the link in my bio to get yours.

When a crisis affects everyone in your life, who should you turn to for support?  ad
 
?Tragedies don’t happen in isolation. The ripple effects are often felt throughout your family and friends. When so many people are trying to process what has happened, some people may hold back on talking to anyone, while others can offload onto the people who don’t have the capacity to give support.
 
?Psychologist Susan Silk developed the concept of Ring Theory after her own experience with breast cancer. She noticed that well-intentioned loved ones and acquaintances would complain to her about the impact of her own illness at a time when she could not offer support to them. She suggests that it helps to think about the rings of support around the crisis, with the people closest to the event at the centre of those rings. Silk says, offer support where you can to those closer to the centre of things, while turning to those further removed from the tragedy for your own support.
 
Of course, there are exceptions to this rule, and it is important to talk openly and honestly with loved ones. When choosing who to reach out to for support, always base that decision on your understanding of the loved one that you already know so well. Some people do find benefit in being able to care for others, even through terrible times. Asking people and respecting their answers is key.
 
For more ideas on how to take care of yourself and support others this holiday season, check out @optionb. @optionb is a programme from @sherylsandberg’s foundation to help those struggling with loss and hardship to feel less alone. You can find guidance on how to show up for loved ones who are struggling and tips for coping at facebook.com/optionbcommunity, and at optionb.org.

One of the most valuable things I’ve learned so far in my life is that confidence is not fixed. It’s not a personality trait that some are born with and others born without.

If you want to feel more confident at something you need to follow these two steps. 

1. Do it as often as you can.

2. Be willing to do it badly and without feeling confident, for as long as it takes to get better.

This might sound controversial but the aim of this video was not to ensure that more people label themselves with depression. What is more important to me is that when your body is sending you signals that all is not ok, that we don’t brush it off, but listen to it. All those signs from how we feel in body and mind have something useful to tell us about what we need, and which of those needs are not being met. So if you are ever asking yourself, “Could I be depressed?” It undoubtedly means that your mental health could do with your attention. You do not need to meet the criteria for a particular disorder to start paying attention to your health and getting any support you may need to do that most effectively.

Anxiety tells us to escape and avoid. That makes sense if we are truly in danger. If we are not in a survival situation and the thing you fear means something to you and the life you want to live, then do it as much as possible. 

Whether it be learning to dance, joining that art class having never before picked up a paint brush, going to a party and challenging yourself to talk to someone new. If fear is holding you back from doing something that would enhance your life, take baby steps at first, and just start. Start today, and again tomorrow, and the next day. Keep going in achievable steps, however small, and don’t stop until it becomes part of your comfort zone ??

If you relate, find tips below 
It’s worth pointing out that high functioning anxiety is not a clinical term or diagnosis. It is not something that is wrong with you. But there is likely plenty of things in your environment contributing to it. So here’s the tips for anyone dealing with persistent high levels of anxiety.

• Some anxiety is normal but chronic  stress leads to an array of long term health problems, so firstly, take it as seriously as any other health issue.
• Not all stress can be chosen. Life just throws it our way. But the stress response is a short-term use tool. It works best when we give the body and mind time for deep rest and replenishment. If you’re honest with yourself, are you making time for that? Are you filling free moments with more stress, like checking your emails while eating your dinner? 
• Which stressors in your life cannot be controlled and which ones could you make decisions to change? Often when we don’t allow enough time for rest and replenishment it’s because we have taken too much on, not all of which may be necessary.
• Look at that tendency to take on too much with curiosity. What do you think that is about? What pressures are you under from others? Which ones are from yourself? Is this lifestyle in any way wrapped up in your sense of self worth and identity?
• Getting a birds eye view on the context of the anxiety is the best way to make the best choices for you about how to improve things. If you don’t have a therapist to do this with, take a big piece of paper and start answering some of the questions in this caption to get you started.

So you’re a highly sensitive person (HSP) what next? What does it even mean anyway?
The recognition that some people experience more sensitivity than others is based on decades of research by psychotherapist Elaine Aaron. But it is crucial to point out that this is not a clinical diagnosis. It is not a disorder that needs changing. You are not flawed in any way. But it’s common for highly sensitive i individuals to feel that way, because people vary greatly in how much their nervous system is aroused in the same situation. So the signs of a highly sensitive person is a description of variation in individuals that can cause us problems if we don’t account for it. 

Sensitivity can have a positive impact on your life as well as negative. Here’s a few examples below:
 You are likely to be highly conscientious and able to concentrate deeply.
You might be especially good at tasks that demand accuracy and speed and detection of error.
You are more likely to be able to process material at a much deeper level.
You might benefit from an ability to reflect on your own thinking and experience and developing self-awareness.

When it comes to working around the negative sides of high sensitivity, I highly recommend Elaine Aaron’s book, The Highly Sensitive person. (For her book on this see the link in my bio under recommended books)

And for more insights from therapy and a book jam packed with tools for managing your mental health in general, the link in my bio takes you to my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before?

The most important thing to know about depression is this:
You don’t have to meet the criteria for depression before you start seeking help. If you know your mental health is dipping, it’s never too soon to start focusing on your wellbeing. And there are lots of avenues to do that. Here’s a few:
• Start educating yourself on the various ways you can help yourself and begin putting what you learn into action.
• Talk to someone you trust. Good quality human connection is more powerful than any of us give it credit for.
• Speak to a professional. They can help you consider your options and support you through your recovery.
• Don’t ignore the signs that your mind and body need attention. The sooner you start to meet your own needs, the quicker you will get back to feeling more yourself.

My golden rules below 

Feel free to share ??

• You don’t have to start with something overwhelming. Pick something that feels challenging but manageable.

• If you can stay in the feared situation for as long as possible your body will habituate to your environment and calm over time.

• During that time use self-soothing skills to help you through it. 

• The more you repeat a behaviour the more it becomes part of your comfort zone. 

• Allow fear to be with you. Don’t push it away.

• Avoidance is the number one thing that feeds anxiety and makes it worse over time. So if there is something that you want to master but it makes you anxious, do it as often as you possibly can.

• Learn how to use basic skills to calm the mind through the body (see book for detailed description of this).

What is that thing you’ve been avoiding because it makes you anxious?

Who can relate? There is no end point to grief. It does not get any less painful to be without your loved one. But your strength to hold it grows as you build your life around it. This is one of the most helpful ideas on grief that I often refer to for both my clients and myself. I think it allows us to be respectful to the intense pain of grief while offering hope for the future. 

I devoted a whole section of my book to grief because nobody gets a free ride on that one. It is something we all face at some point. So, if you’d like to read more, see the links in my bio. Top tip from a Psychologist. More below  

• Hold back on using any “I am” statements. One failure is not a conclusive statement about your character or worthiness as a human being. 
• Failure is easier to recover from and learn from when we focus less on trying to prove ourselves and more on trying IMprove ourselves. Each failure then simply becomes an opportunity for learning to inform new efforts.
• Give yourself permission to feel however you feel about it. Allow that emotion to rise and fall before you start looking for learning. It’s much harder to access that rational thinking when emotion is high.
• Commit to having your own back, no matter what. If you work hard at something and the outcome is not what you hoped, you can either continue to hammer your confidence with self-attack or you can show yourself the compassion and encouragement that you would give to someone you love who had the same experience. When loved ones face a fall, we treat them with compassion because we know it’s what they need to give them strength to get back up. So why would you do anything different for yourself?

If you relate, see tips below ?? 

• It’s not always possible remove all the stress from your life, but when you reach the point of exhaustion, the best way to give yourself a chance of recovery is to reduce stressors where you can.
• This is when the solid back five defenders become crucial. Check in with your nutritional intake, sleep, routine, exercise, nutritional intake and social connection. These are the foundations of good mental health and also the first things we let slide when we’re not doing so great. Making small improvements in these will start to boost your ability to recover from emotional exhaustion.
• Practise listening to your body and mind, asking yourself “what do I need?” And then meeting those needs, even when doing so is difficult to do. For example, it may feel uncomfortable to take time off work if the pressure is on. These scenarios often lead us to ignore the signs that we need time to recover and replenish.
• Never underestimate the power of good social support. Talk to friends. But also spend time with friends that doesn’t involve talking it all through, but is focused on having care-free time out.

?? Feel free to share to raise awareness.
Many people are preoccupied with the question of whether they have depression or not. But the label itself is mostly just a tool for clinicians to easily communicate a group of symptoms. You are the expert on your own experience. So, if you are concerned about your mental health and you know your mental health could improve with some support, then don’t hesitate to seek that support. If professionals are not available to you, trusted friends and family or charity support groups can be a huge boost as you work on recovery. 

It’s also worth noting that symptoms of depression have significant overlap with both menopause and other conditions such as dementia. So always track symptoms over time alongside a professional to help you understand them further.

 For those working independently and trying to learn more about your mind and how to nurture it, see the link in my bio for my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before?

This hits hard How do you feel when someone in your life says one thing but does another? Sometimes it can cause us to doubt ourselves because we want so much to believe in the words they say.  But when there is a disconnect between words and actions I tend to believe that the behaviour carries more weight.

Despite this I do believe that we should always assume positive intent and not rush to judge someone’s actions as malicious until we know more. As soon as we interpret a situation in that way, we are already disconnected and less likely to be able to approach them in a way that will help us fully understand intent.

I’d love to hear what you guys think on this one, from your own experience.

Who can relate to that feeling? What are those things that you feel like doing when you’re low in mood, that you recognise will keep you stuck? 

We might get the urge to listen to sad music, avoid social events, put off things we need to do, and generally hide away from the world. But in those moments, here are just a few of the actions that can help you to lift your mood in the moment:
• Moving your body. Doesn’t need to be the gym. Dance around your house, walk the dog. Anything counts.
• Seek out social connection with people you trust. Isolation keeps low mood going.
• Switch up the sad music for something more uplifting that could shift your emotion state.
• Seek out situations that induce a sense of awe. Being in nature can do this for many people. 

What would you add this this list?

When do you tend to over-explain your choices? Does it happen more with certain people and less with others? Or maybe it happens more when the choice is one that enables you to hold your own needs as equal to others. 

That need we feel to justify ourselves and offer up detailed explanations can be seen as a safety behaviour. An action that helps to bring down the fear associated with holding a boundary. It works temporarily but, in the long term, leads to an increased need to do the same. We find ourselves trapped and unable to hold a boundary if we feel we can’t avoid the disapproval of others.

Maybe asserting yourself in the past led to rejection, abandonment or a complete override of your own needs. Maybe love was conditional. Or maybe it was considered your responsibility to ensure that others remained happy. However the cycle began, it can be broken. It takes time and practise. And it always starts with awareness. So start looking out for those times when you hold a boundary and immediately follow it up with over-explaining and justifying yourself to others.

More insights from therapy in my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? See the link in my bio.

Do you feel guilty any time you need to say no? Is that guilt so intense that you often find it easier to just say yes (when you wanted and needed to say no)? 

Sometimes it makes sense to feel guilty. But sometimes feelings that repeatedly arise and feel out of proportion to the situation, they can be a reflection of the past. So what can we do about it? There is no quick fix to making that feeling disappear. We have to start with understanding the past events that conditioned this response and updating our learning about why the intense guilt comes up and how we want to respond to it as we move forward. Tag your green balls!  Those people who get to be part of your inner circle. The ones you feel safe to be yourself with. The ones you can share your best and most vulnerable moments with. These people that we connect with deeply are essential to our health and longevity. Good quality relationships show up in the research as the most powerful predictor of a long, healthy and happy life. But they are not the only people we need in our lives. There are many people that play a meaningful role in our lives (as we do in theirs) without ever developing a deep and personal connection. I think recognising the value in the diverse relationships that we encounter is one way to appreciate that each offers us something to learn from and feel grateful for. The aim is not to be left with just the people in that inner circle, but to use boundaries effectively so that we can safely experience a variety of relationships. What are your thoughts on this?

Which one do you resonate with most? Depression does not always show up in the way you might expect and that can make it difficult to spot. For example if you don’t feel sadness but instead feel numb and lacking in any emotion, this is a symptom of depression. It just doesn’t get so much air time when people talk about how to spot the signs.

It helps to turn toward all these symptoms with curiosity rather than judgement and criticism. Changes in how we feel often indicate unmet needs. Letting go of whether you should or should not feel this way and looking at it as communication from your body and mind about your needs helps us to identify what they are and start meeting them.

I have sat in countless assessments with people who question whether their suffering is worth my time. The truth is, if you look for someone who has it worse, you will find them. But that does not make your suffering any less valid. Thinking in this way often reflects a lack of self-compassion. If someone you loved unconditionally was suffering in the same way, you wouldn’t hesitate to get them the help they needed. 

The right help is not available for far too many people, for lots of reasons. But if you have access to support, don’t let negative comparison be the reason you hold back from it.

Hands up on the comments who else tends to set a massive goal and then go all for a a week or two before fizzling out? If you do you’re not alone. I think we do this when we favour intensity over consistency. But if we can commit to a change that is small enough to persist at over time then the gains far exceed that short but intense burst. 

So when you want to make a change, focus less on what the results might be and when they will arrive. Instead focus on creating a process that feels easy enough to do consistently. Once it becomes a part of your everyday routine your brain is great at starting to automate some of that for you so that you don’t have to rely on motivation as much as when you started.

Does this thought bias hold you back from taking care of yourself and holding boundaries? It’s the all-or-nothing thinking, also known as black or white thinking. But looking after yourself does not mean you have to put your own needs over and above everyone you care about. Your needs and theirs are not mutually exclusive. It means we have to start seeing our own needs as equal (in importance) to theirs. This is easier said than done if you have spent your life being taught that your needs are something you attend to only when everyone else is satisfied. It takes great effort to turn the tide on a lifetime of habit. But it can be done. It often demands good support, frequent self-reflection and the facing of a few fears. But the rewards are worth it.

The last one is worth a go!  Which of these do you need to start giving yourself permission to do? Sometimes we can hold ourselves back from improving our wellbeing. Here’s a few things that create barriers to optimising our mental health:
• Social pressures. Maybe you feel obliged to stay in a friendship group that is harmful to you. Or maybe you feel pressure to make yourself busy all the time and appear productive when your body is screaming for a rest.
• Misconceptions we have around what it means to seek help and the idea that we need to be in a crisis before we warrant help from professionals.
• Outdated beliefs learned earlier in life that your needs are irrelevant or come last on the list of priorities.

Once we start to acknowledge each of these barriers and see them for what they are, we can start to challenge them and experiment with how good we could feel if we start to place our mental health at the top of our priorities list the way we do with those we love.

Here’s the low-down from a psychologist on why your thoughts seem to run away with you when you’re anxious and what you can do about it. When your threat response is triggered, you are in survival mode. When your brain senses that you might not be safe, speed is more important than accuracy. So your brain does a great job of anticipating threats and jumping to conclusions in order to keep you safe. This means your brain is not taking the time to consider all potential perspectives. It skips all that and takes a short cut to the ideas that could help keep you safe (if that is needed). This speed of processing and a focus on safety leads to bias. We can’t stop that bias. But we can take the power out of it by familiarising ourselves with the types of bias to look out for and naming those thought biases when we notice them. Then we can be open to considering alternative perspectives. Below are a few thought biases that come up with anxiety:

Personalising - this is when we take an ambiguous situation and assume it’s about us. E.g. my friend didn’t wave back. She must hate me.

Catastrophising - when your brain offers up the worst case scenario that hasn’t happened yet and plays it out for you like a movie on repeat, triggering more anxiety.

Spotlight effect - this when we overestimate how much other people are judging us negatively. Something we all do, but do more of when we are anxious.

For more details on this and insights from therapy about how to tackle anxiety for good check out the link in my bio for my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? The bestselling book of 2022 so far on Amazon UK and still a Sunday Times Bestseller for almost 6 months and counting.

• Get to know what your blocking behaviours are. These are the things we do, often without even thinking about it, to numb ourselves. For example, sometimes the first sign of emotional pain is that you are hinting through the fridge for something sweet, or you put off everything else to binge watch tv. Once we build our awareness of how we numb, we can more easily spot when we are struggling.
• It seems counterintuitive to think about welcoming all emotions because our instinct is to push them away. But when we turn toward emotion with curiosity, we no longer need to waste energy fighting it.
• Turning towards it means allowing it to be here. To feel the sensations it brings. And to soothe ourselves as it passes.
• Self-soothing can be anything that helps you to feel safe and comforted  in the moment, without costing you dearly in the long term. 
• Finding words to describe how you feel no writing it down is a helpful way to get some distance from it and see emotions for what they are; an experience washing over you that is temporary.

Nobody can know these things until they know, so these conversations about mental health are helping to squash some of the old misconceptions that were once widely held. Those misconceptions can hold people back in their own recovery. They can also hold people back from being able to support in the most effective way. 

Here are some more tips for how to support someone with their mental health:

* It’s ok if you don’t know how to talk about the painful stuff. You don’t have to be a therapist to be a great support. For example, distraction from your own distress by chatting with a friend can be just as helpful.
* If you are not sure what is the right thing to say, tell them. Let them know that you care about them and want to help, but have no idea how. Ask them what support would be most helpful to them right now.
* Try to help in ways that promote recovery rather than hinder it. For example, if your loved one is managing to cook for themselves, join them but don’t take over the activity. Taking a break from something can make it harder to go back to it. Instead, help like offering childcare while they go to therapy or a doctor makes working on recovery easier.

Do you ever feel stuck in that vicious cycle of social anxiety. You get invited to a social event and the anxiety starts to build. As the event gets closer you can’t stop thinking about it and as the anxiety increases so does that urge to avoid the party altogether. You decide to cancel and instantly feel a sense of relief. Phew! You don’t have to face the world today. You then enjoy the calm of staying in your comfort zone until the next time you have to face groups of people and the cycle begins all over again. 

When we break this down in therapy you can start to see the ways you can break the cycle and rebuild your confidence around people. Below are a few thoughts on this:

Avoidance gives you that instant relief but feeds the anxiety in the long term. Going against that urge to avoid the feared situation becomes the big challenge of therapy.
Escaping the feared situation too early, before the body has calmed, also maintains the anxiety in the long term because it reconfirms the belief that you can only feel safe once you escape.
You don’t have to face the most feared situations first. When you do that you are more likely to be overwhelmed and give up. Start with something that feels a challenge but manageable.
Get support from family, friends or a therapist. Having good quality support greatly improves the chances of success.

Are you trying to support a loved one but not sure what is the best way to do that? Here’s a few tips below:

• It’s ok not to talk about the problem every time you see them. For example, if someone is grieving it can be a welcome relief to spend time being distracted by a friend for a while. 
• If you are talking about their problems, ask open questions that require more than a yes or no answer. For example, instead of “Are you ok?” Try “what are you thinking?” 
• Support in ways that help them toward their recovery. For example, giving them a lift to a therapy appointment, rather than taking something off their hands that they are already managing.
• If you are the main cater or support for someone it’s ok to get support for yourself too. If you look after yourself you will be much more able to sustain a good level of care.

No. 4 is often overlooked. Which one resonates for you? 
When someone you love has depression it’s normal to feel confused about how best to help and support them. You fear getting it wrong and making things worse. 
Here’s a few tips below:
• Don’t expect yourself to be the therapist. Nothing is more powerful than a friend you can rely on to keep calling in and spending time with you even when you’re not at your best.
• If you’re not sure the best way to support your loved one, it is ok to ask. Let them know you love them and want the best for them and how important it is to you to be able to support them. Then ask them what kind of support they need. That takes the guess work out of it for both of you. 
• Prioritise your own health too. It is not selfish. It is the only way you can continue to care for others in the long term. It’s ok to get your own therapy to help you along the way. 
• If you struggle to talk about things, it’s ok to be that friend who offers some distraction from how they feel for a while. Do what you can to show them you care.

TIPS FOR BUILDING CONFIDENCE BELOW: 

• Do not wait to feel confident before starting that thing you want to master. It won’t arrive spontaneously.
• Action builds confidence over time. 
• Rather than big, one-off actions, go for consistency over intensity. Repetition that you can sustain is crucial for building confidence.
• You don’t have to overwhelm yourself. Start small and manageable in the stretch zone where you make most progress with performance. 

The model in this video is adapted from Karl Rohnke's Comfort, Stretch and Panic model, which was developed based on the Yerkes-Dodson law. This law posits that peak performance happens when people experience a moderate amount of pressure.

Do you say yes when you want to say no? Do you try to say no and then backtrack if the other person shows disapproval? It’s not easy to hold ground if we are used to prioritising the wishes of others over our own needs. We start to question our original decision and convince ourselves that this time we can dismiss our own needs. But when that happens over and over again, we start to lose sight of how and when to respond to our own needs. 

A big challenge that comes with breaking that cycle, is tolerating the discomfort of disapproval from others. Not easy. One way to do that is to stay closely connected to the reasons for holding that particular boundary and your values that is based on. Even choices that seem small can be a significant part values that you’re trying to live by, so keep in mind the reasons they are important to you, even when others may not agree.

Do you feel resentful in your relationships? One reason this can happen is that we give more than we can sustain, feel exhausted and look to the other person to do something similar in return. When they don’t, we feel resentful. Then the people pleaser in us says, “If I just try harder…if I am more productive, more caring, more helpful, more beautiful, more everything…then they will do the same and I will feel more worthy, more loved.”

If the other person still does not respond, we go round the cycle again and resentment continues to build. 

But what if we were to reflect on those feelings with curiosity? To get honest with ourselves and ask, “what are my needs?” and then commit to taking responsibility for meeting them. Doing this work within the self can break the cycle of resentment and shift the dynamics in a relationship. So nurturing the self is nurturing your relationship.

If setting boundaries in relationships is a new thing for you then therapists can be hugely helpful for this. The task is to carefully work out what boundaries will help you to sustain the relationship without it damaging your mental health. For some, that might be setting rules around how often you see them or how much time you spend together. For others it may be practicing the art of saying no. It can be a real struggle to be assertive or express our own needs in relationships in which we feel a sense of duty. So taking time to get clarity on the relationship in therapy can be life changing.

?? Who can relate? You can talk for hours to friends but the idea of going to therapy fills you with fear. If that is you, here are a few tips from me, a Clinical Psychologist who has supported countless people through that first therapy session:
• The majority of people walk into their first session feeling nervous and unsure how to articulate everything they want to say. The majority of people then walk out feeling calmer and more hopeful and inspired for their therapy journey.
• The therapy room often becomes your sanctuary. The one place you can go to and express yourself unapologetically, knowing you will not be judged. 
• It’s normal to worry that your story may shock the therapist. But it’s almost impossible to shock a therapist. 
• You cannot cover everything in the first session. Your therapist does not need you to explain everything in a specific order or with absolute clarity. They will take notes if they might need to come back to something later.
• If you feel nervous or fear judgement, say it. Tell the therapist how you feel and they will help you to understand and work through it. That is what they are there for.
• Take all your fears with you and see if therapy could help you change your life. I’m rooting for you!

Which of these signs do you notice in your relationships? Is the other person using your emotions to get what they want? Emotional manipulation can be very subtle and hard to spot. But when it becomes pervasive some of the telltale signs can be feelings of confusion about how you keep overriding your own knowledge, instincts and values when making decsions. Increasing self-doubt and uncertainty in your own judgement leads you to give even more power to the other person. Once you start to notice when this is happening, there is opportunity for change. Starting to put in new boundaries with someone who has previously had full control in a relationship is not an easy process. So getting support from a trusted friend or therapist to help on that path is often a good idea. Are you in a constant battle to feel good enough? When we feel this way the most natural response is to look outward, to others, for their idea of what we should be. But this means the goalposts are constantly moving and we are at the mercy of whoever happens to be around. 

It is normal, healthy behaviour to adapt how you behave around different social groups. But if your sense of self-worth is entirely dependent on the opinions of others you are handing over control of your wellbeing to other people. 

One of the remedies for this is to get clarity on your own values. Try spending some time answering some questions like these, to start building a sense of what matters to you from the inside out:
• What kind of person do you want to be? 
• How do you want to contribute to your family, community and the world?
• When tough times hit, how do you want to approach problems? What attitude could you take that would make you proud?
• What are the aspects of your life that matter most to you? How do you want to show up in those areas of your life? 

I provide lots of in-depth tools for getting clear on your own values in my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? See link in my bio for all offers.

The last one is so important ?? Who else thinks of the worst case scenario before any other possible outcome? If you do, it’s because you are human and your brain does such a great job at keeping you alive. But not every situation that triggers anxious thoughts is life threatening. And those thoughts are your brains attempt to be alert to the possibilities. They are not concrete predictions of what will happen. So learning to step back from catastrophising thoughts and see them for what they are, is an empowering life skill that can give you back a sense of control from periods of anxiety. 

I started this video with, “How to get rid of catastropising thoughts”, because it’s a question I get asked a lot. But, in reality, you never get rid of them. You wouldn’t want to. But they help you to choose which ones you act on and which ones are not helping you. For example, as I walked on a coastal path with my children, my youngest ran towards the edge. Despite the fact that we were a long way from the edge, I was able to grab him and prevent a more dangerous situation because my brain had already played out the worst case scenario for me. A very useful catastrophising thought. But when my sister is travelling to see me and I catastrophise that she could be in a traffic accident, these thoughts are no use to me as it’s a situation I cannot control. They will only serve to make me anxious and change nothing about the outcome.

Avoidance feeds self-doubt and the more you avoid something, the more you will believe in that narrative that says, I would never have been good enough anyway.

Tackling self-doubt demands courageous action in the direction of something that matters to you, something that feels so important that it overrides your need to feel comfortable and ready. 

When you stop waiting for self-doubt to disappear, when you make this radical decision to let that self-doubt come along for the ride, as you do that scary thing, it won't hold you back anymore.

 I see a lot of misinformation on social media about self doubt and how to tackle it. So I put a few of those into this video. ?? What does anxiety make you do? Everyone responds to high anxiety in different ways but the key factor that all of those actions have in common is that they work (in the short term) to bring some relief from the anxiety. For example, when you go back and triple check the door is locked you get this small moment of, “Phew! All is safe.” But the reason we have to keep going back to check more than once is because that moment of relief doesn’t last long. 

In contrast, the things that will help us address anxiety in the long term tend to be those things that force us to sit with the anxiety in the short term. Not easy. Not comfortable. But definitely possible and definitely worth it.

Ouch!  Shall I post a few outtakes from this video? Let me know in the comments! We all get overworked and tired every now and then but burnout is more than tiredness. Burnout is when stress becomes chronic and has a detrimental effect on other areas in your life. 

Signs of burnout include chronic exhaustion alongside restlessness and trouble sleeping, poor self-care such as diet and exercise. Other signs include repeated emotional distress, such as anxiety, low mood, or anger outbursts. You may notice your performance at work is going down, while you feel you are working harder than ever, you may also start feeling disconnected with loved ones and struggle to get along as well as you normally do.
Below are some tips on how to prevent burnout but if you want more on this and how to make stress start working for you, see the link in my bio for my no.1 Sunday Times Bestseller, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? It’s currently half price (£7.49) in hardback and free when you sign up to Audible. 
A few tips on burnout:
 Start working out what you can say no to. Often we feel obliged to say yes to every request or opportunity. When our health is in question, it’s a pretty good reason to practice the art of saying no to things that are not an absolute priority.
 Prioritise self-care. Get back to basics because they are the foundations of good mental and physical health. Make sleep, healthy food, hydration, exercise and social time top of your to do list. And don’t underestimate the power of these things to build your resilience.
 Re-think what matters. We are vulnerable to burnout when we are working hard on something that is not in line with our own values. Instructions on this in my book. 
 Get support. If you are worried about your mental health in any way, seeking support from a trusted friend or a professional is key. Human connection is a powerful tool. Use it.

How do you feel when someone in your life says one thing but does another? Sometimes it can cause us to doubt ourselves because we want so much to believe in the words they say.  But when there is a disconnect between words and actions I tend to believe that the behaviour carries more weight.

Despite this I do believe that we should always assume positive intent and not rush to judge someone’s actions as malicious until we know more. As soon as we interpret a situation in that way, we are already disconnected and less likely to be able to approach them in a way that will help us fully understand intent.

I’d love to hear what you guys think on this one, from your own experience.

Important to remember this.
Who else gets that rush of guilt when you have to say no or hold a boundary? Join the club! But that guilt might be more to do with learning earlier in life that the needs and feelings of others always trump your own. That is was your job to keep others happy. Sometimes guilt can tell us that we are not doing the right thing. But guilt is not a fact. Listen to it. Then make your decision  taking into account your needs too. 

Free free to share. More videos @drjulie 

For more insights from therapy that you can use to your advantage every day, see the link in my bio for the UKs top selling book of 2022 so far, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before?

Relatable? Tips for people pleasers below 

• Balancing your own needs with those of others is not a sign of selfishness. It is a sign of emotional maturity. When we start to set boundaries, how we frame it in our minds is crucial to help us with the guilt feelings that often come up when we start making changes.
• If you notice that your identity is wrapped up in your care taking roles, this can make it even more difficult to make changes. It’s ok to still have that but there may be room to expand your sense of who you are to include other areas of your life and other skills that you have.
• If you are no longer sure what your own preferences are because you have always deferred to what others want, then it’s time to start experimenting with small decisions and reflecting on your own experiences. 
• Keep reminding yourself that it is possible to say no and still be a good person.

• To build confidence, go where you have none. Be willing to step out of your comfort zone and stay there for a while.

The most important thing to know about depression is this:
You don’t have to meet the criteria for depression before you start seeking help. If you know your mental health is dipping, it’s never too soon to start focusing on your wellbeing. And there are lots of avenues to do that. Here’s a few:
• Start educating yourself on the various ways you can help yourself and begin putting what you learn into action.
• Talk to someone you trust. Good quality human connection is more powerful than any of us give it credit for.
• Speak to a professional. They can help you consider your options and support you through your recovery.
• Don’t ignore the signs that your mind and body need attention. The sooner you start to meet your own needs, the quicker you will get back to feeling more yourself.

Do you ever find that when you try to stop thinking about something, those thoughts stick around even more? Trying to block out certain thoughts can cause us more problems than when we let them occur and then pass naturally. The key is in choosing which thoughts we will hold onto and focus our attention on and which thoughts we will not give the spotlight to. The metaphor in this video is one I often use to help describe what we do in mindfulness. You don’t block out or deliberately hold onto any particular thoughts. You notice each one as it occurs and let it pass naturally. During that practise you begin to notice that focusing the spotlight of your attention on a thought encourages it to stick around for longer. While trying to stop a thought from arriving makes them more persistent at trying to get their time in the spotlight. Have you ever tried this? Let me know what you think in the comments.

Which one resonated for you the most? These are just a few of the factors that can lead to procrastination. For anyone looking for tips on how to overcome it so that you can get on with the things that matter to you, I’ve included a few points below. It is about to go into its 20th week in The Sunday Times Bestseller list and still sitting at no.1. If you’d prefer me to read it for you it’s free when you sign up to Audible. 

Points for tackling procrastination:

Turn from the self-criticism to curiosity. So rather than get hard on yourself for it, ask yourself why it might be happening and be ready to get honest with yourself.
If a task feels overwhelming, don’t expect yourself to do it all at once. Break it down into tiny steps that don’t feel so daunting.
Start your day with the hardest task first. 
Start questioning your relationship with failure. Perfectionism makes us afraid to fail which can create a block to progress and risk taking. Learning about growth mindset can help this. Check out my other videos on growth mindset or read more in the book. 
Check that the goal is your own and not someone else’s. Keep connected to why you are working toward this thing to help you over the hump of not feeling like it.

What does anxiety make you do? All of the actions in this video are safety behaviours. These are things that we do to feel a little safer in the moment. They are highly addictive because they work in the short-term. They give us that instant relief from the anxiety. Moments later the anxiety returns and increases our need to do the same thing again. That is how rituals and compulsions can build up over time.

Do you notice that when you’re stressed your emotions have more power over you? Emotional reasoning might have something to do with it. That’s because the brain is much more likely to use short-cuts (in the form of thought bias) when we are under stress. Emotional reasoning is a biased thought pattern in which we assume, “I feel it, therefore it must be true.” Here’s a few points about emotional reasoning that you need to know:

* Feelings are not facts. They are information and ideas offered to us by the brain as a way to make sense of the world around us.
* Part of the power of any emotion is in how much we believe it to be a true and fair reflection of reality.
* Therefore, is an emotion is not a fair reflection of reality but we are taking it to be so, then we experience distress unnecessarily. 

For more details on this and other thought biases, and how to deal with them get your copy of my number one Sunday Times Bestseller, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? Worldwide and audiobook links are in bio.

For tips on supporting your loved one with social anxiety, see caption below

 It’s ok to not have all the answers. You can be a huge support to someone’s recovery without being a therapist. 
 When things are difficult to understand our brains tend to take a short cut and suggest something before we know any better. That is judgement. Try to hold back on settling with those judgements and instead always focus on trying to understand.
 The best help is always in the direction of recovery. For example, if my friend finds social situations difficult and I suggest we avoid them together, the anxiety is likely to get worse. If I agree to go with them and be a support while they challenge their fears, that is going to help them move forward. 
 Keep in mind that the person who is socially anxious may never pick up the phone to call you or suggest going out. But that doesn’t mean they don’t want to connect and spend time with you. Keep reminding yourself of that if you start to feel hurt by it. But equally, it’s ok to talk to them about that and work out a compromise.

What a look!  My poor husband  Who did you last compare yourself to and how did it leave you feeling? Inspired or envious? Did you turn it into a plan of action to improve your own life or use it as a weapon of self-loathing? When you hear people tell you to just stop comparing yourself, it’s very easy to say, much harder to do. That’s because we are built to be aware of what other people around us are doing and how it’s working out for them. It’s all part of living in social groups. But never before have we had access to images of other people from across the world. And never before have all those people had access to software that could transform images so dramatically that they are almost unrecognisable from the original. So in our new world, comparison can quickly go from being useful to self-destructive. Keep a close eye on how much comparison you are doing and how it is impacting on you.

We don’t have to climb mountains or hike through jungles to get the benefits of being outdoors. We can take a walk with a friend, hop off the bus a few stops early, or try a new route. If we can combine that with some form of green space on a regular basis it can have a significant impact on many aspects of our health and wellbeing. Time in nature reduces the levels of stress hormones in your body, calms anxiety and lifts your mood. When we combine it with exercise it builds our resilience to stress and makes us more sensitive to feelings of joy and pleasure.

Research shows us that at least 20 minutes in nature each week is associated with good health and wellbeing. But don’t stop there. The benefits seem to peak at between three to five hours outside. So I challenge you to find a way to spend more time outdoors today, tomorrow and the next day.

How will you add into your routine some more time to be outdoors this week?

When anxiety is high do you feel like you can’t catch your breath? This happens because your body is trying to get in as much oxygen as possible to fuel the stress response. For some it can feel like you might suffocate but in reality you already have plenty of oxygen in your body. But if you can change that fast and shallow breathing for something deeper and slower, you can prevent the anxiety from escalating. 

One easy technique to try is the one in this video called square breathing. You can find a window or picture frame to help you focus on slowing the breath and counting in 4 seconds, hold 4 seconds, out 4 seconds and hold 4 seconds. 

Of course, if the timings don’t fit for you then you can adjust. The main aim is that you slow the breathing down. It can take several minutes so stick with it. Any time that your mind wonders, bring your attention back to counting the breath. Let me know how you get on!

When does the mental filter come up for you? 

The mental filter is a common thought bias that happens to us all and has the potential to make us feel much worse. 

If you would like more details on how thought biases are making you feel worse and what you can do about it, I cover this in my new bestselling book. Why has nobody told me this before? (link in bio).

So any time you notice that you are holding onto thoughts that focus on threat and loss like this, don’t let it go unchecked. Notice the bias, label it and take time to consciously consider the other information available to you. These simple tools can be really effective if we put in a bit of practice and use them regularly. Give it a try and let me know what you notice.

Do you ever fall into that “all or nothing” trap? Black and white thinking is a cognitive bias that we all do at times, but we tend to do more of it when we are stressed (more below).

 For more help on this check out my No.1 Bestselling book - Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? It is packed with insights from therapy to help everyone boost their mental health and thrive in the face of life’s ups and downs. It is now available worldwide (link in bio).

Something small happens and, “the whole day is ruined!” 

This tendency to think in absolutes can make it harder to deal with hurdles because it triggers more intense emotional reactions. If we can only consider something a complete success or a complete failure then we are vulnerable to feeling like a complete failure much of the time. 

So look out for that all or nothing/ black or white thinking. When you notice it appear, call it out. Acknowledge it is a bias that is not helpful. The process of recognising the bias for what it is, will help to take some of the power out of it. Then you can consider alternative perspectives. Give it a go.

As It’s Valentine’s Day this week here is some food for thought on things we do that put strain on our relationships, whether they are romantic relationships, friendships or family relationships. 

There is a chapter on relationships in my new book - Why has nobody told me this before? Available worldwide links in bio.

For example, the natural urge to try and win arguments by proving the other person wrong. The answers to conflict are rarely black and white, so creating a lasting relationship inevitably includes playing with the balance of wanting to be seen as right and wanting to reconnect. This doesn’t mean we should let everything slide. Every conflict is a judgement call and a chance to learn. 

Another is our tendency to expect the other person to anticipate our needs or wants without her communicating them clearly. Voicing our needs can feel highly uncomfortable if we have been taught to squash our needs and prioritise others. But practising this in small ways can be life changing. It not only improves our chances of getting our needs met but also prevents the other person from having to endure the guessing game and suffering the consequences when they get it wrong. 

For more on relationships check out my number 1 Sunday Times Bestseller, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? Links in bio to get yours.

#

Can you relate? If you can then you are doing a bully’s job for them. Gaslighting has a devastating impact on mental health (continued below).

For more on how to tackle self-doubt and build confidence, check out my new No.1 Bestseller, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? See link in bio to order (also available as an audiobook).

But what if you are engaging in those same behaviours toward yourself? For those who have experienced abusive relationships in the past, we can internalise the voice of the abuser and learn to treat ourselves in the same way, even long after we have escaped the situation. 

1. You blame yourself for everything. You'll make excuses for other peoples behaviour but if you make a mistake you believe it says something fundamental about who you are as a person.
2. You never trust in your own judgement but you see the opinions of others as a much more credible source, so you live in an almost constant state of self-doubt and look to someone else for clarity.
3. You invalidate of ignore your own feelings because you have come to believe that you are oversensitive and overreact, so you don't know which emotions to listen to anymore. 

For more on how to tackle self-doubt and build confidence, check out my new book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? See link in bio to order.
