Do you get caught up trying to control things you can’t control? When we do stress goes up, mood goes down and life becomes much harder than it needs to be. 

 For more help on this check out my No.1 Bestseller - Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? It is packed with insights from therapy to help everyone boost their mental health and thrive in the face of life’s ups and downs. It is available worldwide link in bio.

So I think it’s a great move, when you have a lot on your mind, to make the distinction between things that you can change and things you can’t. One example is the tendency we have to get caught up in other people’s mistakes or choices. It can come from a compassionate place and be rooted in love and concern for another. But if we find ourselves ruminating over these things, it can be less helpful than focusing on the things we can influence, such as our own choices and behaviours. 

So, in a situation that cannot be completely controlled or changed, what matters most to you? Who do you want to be within that imperfect world? How could you conduct yourself in a way that would make you proud and grateful that you made that choice?

??? Has anxiety become too much for you right now? If you are struggling with anxiety but don’t know where to start I have put a few tips below  

 Also if you found this video helpful then you will love my new no.1 bestselling book / audiobook - Why has nobody told me this before? I talk  in great detail about anxiety in the book. See link in bio to order for UK, USA & worldwide 

Golden rules for tackling anxiety:
• You don’t have to start with something overwhelming. Pick something that feels challenging but manageable.
• If you can stay in the feared situation for as long as possible your body will habituate to your environment and calm over time.
• During that time use self-soothing skills to help you through it. 
• The more you repeat a behaviour the more it becomes part of your comfort zone. 
• Allow fear to be with you. Don’t push it away.
• Avoidance is the number one thing that feeds anxiety and makes it worse over time. So if there is something that you want to master but it makes you anxious, do it as often as you possibly can.
• Learn how to use basic skills to calm the mind through the body (see book for detailed description of this).

What is that thing you have been avoiding because it makes you anxious?

One way that some people can find helpful for grounding when they feel overwhelmed with emotion (whether that is anxiety or another emotion) is to use something that calls your attention to your senses. That is why ice or cold water can be a great tool (more below).

For more help on anxiety check out my No.1 Bestselling book - Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? It is packed with insights from therapy to help everyone boost their mental health. It has sections on anxiety, stress, low mood, emotional pain, motivation grief and more. It is available worldwide (link in bio).

To use ice for grounding, hold the ice in your hands, run it along your arms or face. Notice the sensations. The temperature, texture on your skin. If you are feeling overwhelmed with distress, splashing ice cold water on your face (also know as ice diving) can help to reduce your heart rate while at the same time providing a strong anchor for your grounding technique. This simply means, those strong physical sensations help to bring your attention to the here and now. So, if you tend to get overwhelmed, stock up on ice and give it a try.

Can you relate to any of these? Signs of depression can be complex and vary between people. Fluctuation in mood and general wellbeing is normal but if symptoms persist for weeks or months it’s time to reach out and speak to someone (continued below).

For more help on this check out my No.1 Bestselling book - Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? It is packed with insights from therapy to help everyone boost their mental health and thrive in the face of life’s ups and downs. It is available worldwide (links in bio).

 I have listed below some of the psychological symptoms of depression:

- [ ] Continuous low mood or sadness
- [ ] Feeling hopeless and helpless
- [ ] Low self-esteem
- [ ] Feeling tearful
- [ ] Feeling guilt-ridden
- [ ] Feeling irritable and intolerant of others
- [ ] Having no motivation or losing interest in things you used to enjoy
- [ ] Difficulty making decisions
- [ ] Feeling anxious or worried
- [ ] Rumination 
- [ ] Avoiding contact with friends

Physical symptoms include:
- [ ] Sleep disturbance 
- [ ] Appetite changes
- [ ] Low libido
- [ ] Unexpected aches and pains
- [ ] Low energy

If you are ever concerned about your mental health, seek professional support.

???Who can relate? If you live in England then the word sorry is something you hear on a daily basis. It can be considered good manners in a variety of situations. But when apologising is driven by more than just cultural habits it can be linked to low self-esteem, shame and trauma.

For more on confidence & self-esteem check out my no.1 bestselling new book ”Why has nobody told me this before?” (worldwide links in bio).

So look out for those apologies today. Notice the impact they have on how you feel. Also notice what feelings come up if you try resisting an unnecessary apology. This can help us to understand what’s going on in more depth. 

Stopping all the unnecessary apologies won’t fix low self-esteem by itself. But it will help. Changing these small behaviours is a significant piece of the larger puzzle.

Who else sets a goal then feels like they’ve failed when they get off track? Throughout my whole career, I have never seen recovery, or any positive change, go in a straight line. I talk about this in more detail my Number One Sunday Times Bestseller, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? See link in bio to order.

When you make a commitment to work on recovery, it’s easy to get frustrated and self-critical when you have a bad day or a tough week. You may believe that you have gone back to square one. But this is not true. 

Ups and downs are a normal and expected part of recovery. The key is recognising those bad days are temporary and refocus on the skills that you need to get you back on track. You cannot undo the progress you have made and the things you have learned along the way. So keep going!

How do you keep your nerves in check under pressure? This is something I covered in detail in my new book, and I made full use of those skills for this interview with Lorraine live on TV this week. It was my first time in the studio and when TV is live, there is no way to edit out mistakes. I have listed below a few of the skills that I used to stay calm and focused and each of them is covered in more detail with step by step instructions in the book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? (Link in bio for USA, UK and Europe).

* I took control of my breathing. I took two short inbreaths for every longer outbreath. This kept my heart rate and all the physical signs of anxiety from escalating.
* I took control of the focus of my attention. I did not allow myself to spent too much time with catastrophising thoughts of what could go wrong (which would only make me more nervous).
* Instead I kept in mind all the times I had faced high pressure scenarios in the past and delivered. 
* While in the interview, surrounded by crew and equipment I knew that distraction could prevent me from fully hearing and understanding a question so I was very intentional about making it a priority to focus exclusively on each question despite everything else going on.
* I reframed my anticipatory anxiety as excitement and entered the experience with the intention of enjoying it, which I did.
* I allowed the stress to be present, knowing that the increase in alertness would help me focus and perform.

So if you have to do something brand new that fills you with fear, don’t let that fear keep you from it. Use all the tools in my book to help you along the way, then enjoy the ride.

…It reminds me that, no matter how tough things get and how broken we can feel at times, healing can happen. It reminds me that healing is not about pretending the worst never happened. By doing the work to heal, we can find new learning, new strength and new meaning from the hardest of seasons. 

More and more, I see courageous people online sharing their stories of recovery from hardship with the aim of helping others. To me, this is Kintsugi in practice. The more these difficult conversations happen, the more we learn as a society that psychological injury is a part of life. The more we learn that it can be a pivotal part of the story, but doesn’t have to be the end of the story. With healing and recovery we can find new beauty and meaning in life. 

In addition to this, if we can recover once, we can recover again. It gives us all hope that, even when it feel like everything is in pieces, we can get there.

Do you dismiss how you feel when it doesn’t match what you expect from yourself? 

 More on this can be found in my new book “Why has nobody told me this before?” Link in bio

???I see that happen a lot when people are in pain or struggle. 
Especially in depression when the most prominent feeling is emptiness and numbness rather than the tearful sadness that you might expect. 

When we add judgement to painful human emotion it tends to add to the pain, not take it away. 

It helps to turn toward emotion (or a lack of) with curiosity rather than judgement and criticism. Changes in how we feel often indicate unmet needs. Letting go of whether you should or should not feel this way and looking at it as communication from your body and mind about your needs helps us to identify what they are and start meeting them.

When we feel painful emotion the most natural human response is to pull away, escape them and avoid. We block them out with anything that feels safe and pleasurable. But when we do that, the painful emotions don’t always disappear forever. We find ourselves trapped in cycles of addictive behaviours that keep the emotion at bay for just a short time. 

The way we guide people to process painful emotion in therapy is to allow the emotion to be there, turn towards it and feel it, while soothing yourself through the process with skills that help you to tolerate the distress. This enables the emotion to take its natural course and wash over you. Emotions come in waves so we know they will increase in intensity, peak and then come back down again.

Can you relate? Do you ever come away from a social interaction and tell yourself that the other person doesn’t like you? If you do then you’re not alone. Hollywood has a lot to answer for when it comes to our expectations for relationships. It’s almost impossible to find a realistic portrayal of a lasting romantic relationship. 

I have a whole section on relationships in my new book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? See link in bio to get your copy 

In real relationships it’s ok to feel bored sometimes and not constantly head over heels. Finding others attractive does not necessarily mean you are in the wrong relationship. Your partners happiness is not entirely your responsibility. You are allowed to hold boundaries and say no. You can disagree, enjoy different hobbies, and spend time apart. 

Observing how people behave in other relationships and talking to friends can help us to work on our own relationship, but comparison is not helpful because we never really get to see what happens behind closed doors so the relationships of others may not be as rosy as we imagine from afar. 

Do you find yourself comparing your relationship to others?

If you know that Christmas is a tough time of year for you, then plan to do the best by yourself over the next couple of weeks. The specifics may depend on your situation. But you are the expert on your own experience. So, whatever that looks like for you, commit to having your own back and doing what helps in the long term. Remember that loneliness tells you that you’re alone, even when you are not. And hopelessness tells you to give up when you most need to dig in and try again.

A few insights into what it’s like to start therapy:

- It’s normal to be nervous
- It’s normal to worry about making sense or getting everything in the right order.
- It’s normal to feel like you have to fit everything into the first session.
- It’s normal that there is never enough time to cover everything.
- Any psychologist or therapist with experience will know all this and be able to reassure you.
- After the first session nerves it gets easier and easier. It won’t take long for the therapy room to become a kind of sanctuary.

?? What does anxiety make you do? Everyone responds to high anxiety in different ways but the key factor that all of those actions have in common is that they work (in the short term) to bring some relief from the anxiety. For example, when you go back and triple check the door is locked you get this small moment of, “Phew! All is safe.” But the reason we have to keep going back to check more than once is because that moment of relief doesn’t last long. 

In contrast, the things that will help us address anxiety in the long term tend to be those things that force us to sit with the anxiety in the short term. Not easy. Not comfortable. But definitely possible and definitely worth it.

My book has a whole section dedicated to anxiety. For your copy, see link in bio.

Look out for these! Research shows that certain behaviour patterns are most associated with relationship breakups. 

Research suggests that contempt is the strongest predictor of divorce. Contempt is more than criticism. It involves attacking someone from a position of moral superiority. Contempt is when we get truly mean. We call them names, disrespect them, ridicule and roll our eyes.

Despite the research, the presence of these behaviours in your relationship does not automatically mean it will end in a breakup. Becoming aware of how damaging these behaviours can be, and noticing when they occur, is the first step towards change.

What does anxiety make you do? All of the actions in this video are safety behaviours. These are things that we do to feel a little safer in the moment. They are highly addictive because they work in the short-term. They give us that instant relief from the anxiety. Moments later the anxiety returns and increases our need to do the same thing again. That is how rituals and compulsions can build up over time.

This simple formulation can show us how we get stuck but it can also show us the way out. More on this in my new book  out now worldwide (link in bio).

Your thoughts, behaviour, and physical state influence how your emotions. They are closely entwined like weaves in a basket so we often experience them all as one and it can be hard to separate them. But when we do, it is easier to establish what we are doing that keeps us stuck and what changes may need to happen if we want to feel different..

Feel free to share/repost this video 

More info...
Any moment in your life can be broken down into these 4 aspects of your experience (there are others, but it’s easier to start with these 4). 
Your thoughts, emotions, physical sensations and behaviour are all closely connected. So much so that it can be hard to notice all of them individually. We just notice our one overall experience. But when we practice noticing each one individually, we can build awareness of how they impact on each other.

Most people can tell you which feelings they have that they want to change. But we can’t just magically change how we feel. However, we have more power over our emotions than most people think. Each of these 4 aspects of our experience impact on each other so heavily that if we start to change some of them, the others start to change too. 

A great exercise to try is to draw out the 4 squares (it doesn’t have to resemble a hot cross bun like this one). Bring to mind one moment in time and see if you can write down what your thoughts, emotions, physical sensations and behaviours were. It is also great to then do the same for a positive moment when you felt at your best. 

In particular, take note of the three boxes that you can influence. For example, when you felt at your best, what was the focus of your attention? What did your thoughts sound like? What were you doing? How does that compare to the more difficult moments?

For more details on these anxiety tips, see below:

• Grounding - when anxious our minds tend to be worrying about something that may or may not happen in the future. You can use each of your senses to ground you in the here and now. Fidgets are a popular choice but it can be as simple as holding onto the desk in front of you or pushing your feet into the ground and noticing the sensations on the soles of your feet. Anything that helps to you to focus on the here and now.

• Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR). You can find guided PMR meditations online. Let me know in the comments if you’d like me to put one on my YouTube channel for you. It involves tensing each muscle group and releasing. Can be very helpful with relaxation after a tough day.
• Breathing - a powerful and fast acting technique for calming anxiety. Focus on taking longer and deeper breaths as breathing becomes fast and shallow under stress. Try to make the our breath longer than the inbreath. A great technique to use when in public as nobody even needs to know you are doing it.

Who else wishes it was that simple? If we could just decide to think something different and then everything would be ok. Then my job wouldn’t exist. So here are a few key points on stress taken from my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? 
• Simply reducing stress in your life is not the only answer. Most people don’t get to choose the stressors they have to face.
• Some stress is beneficial. It helps us stay alert, focus and perform at our best.
• Stress is useful in the short-term. But when it persists for long periods and we don’t have a chance to recover then it becomes chronic and damaging for our health.
• Finding ways to lean out of the stress and replenish does not have to be a big event like a holiday. Creating small moments of rest each day can be a big help.
• Instead of catching up on emails between meetings, take 10 minutes to walk around the block or sit in your car and close your eyes. Then you will be more able to take on new stress in the next meeting.
• Take back those small, in-between moments in your day when you might otherwise be checking your phone. Resist the urge to fill the time and recognise the potential for a little replenishment.

By book covers a more in-depth look at how we can deal with stress. See link in bio

??? Do you dismiss how you feel when it doesn’t match what you expect from yourself? I see that happen a lot when people are in pain or struggle. Especially in depression when the most prominent feeling is emptiness and numbness rather than the tearful sadness that you might expect. 

When we add judgement to painful human emotion it tends to add to the pain, not take it away. 

It helps to turn toward emotion (or a lack of) with curiosity rather than judgement and criticism. Changes in how we feel often indicate unmet needs. Letting go of whether you should or should not feel this way and looking at it as communication from your body and mind about your needs helps us to identify what they are and start meeting them.

Don’t try this at home This was the scariest video I have ever made but we have to hit #worldmentalhealthday with a bang! We have to get the message out there that some of the simplest changes in lifestyle can lead to powerful changes in how we feel. Exercise is one way to start influencing how you feel.

 Behind the scenes coming soon! 
A massive thank you to @gymshark for sponsoring this video and helping us spread the word that moving your body on the daily can have a 
life-changing impact on mental health.

The stress response is there to help us move and meet the demands of our environment. So some stress helps us perform. But repeatedly triggering the stress response without allowing for replenishment in between is like driving your car in second gear along the motorway. At some point it’s going to do some serious damage. 

There is much advice out there telling us to eliminate stress from our lives. But that is not realistic as most people face huge stressors that they can’t control. When that is the case, we must prioritise our natural defences: •exercise
•sleep
•nutrition
•social connection

They seem like the basics, but they are the foundations for good health that strengthen you to face whatever life throws your way. 

So on World Mental Health Day help us spread the message that simple things go a long way.  Feel free to share and repost this message

Do you overthink everything?
If you do here are a few insights from therapy.
* Ruminating about things in the past is associated with low mood and depression. But if there are memories that still affect you, returning to them in a new way to try and make sense of them may be necessary. 
* Worrying about everything that may or may not happen in the future is not the same as planning for the future you want. 
* Write worries down and then look at which of those can be prevented by some sort of reasonable action. If they are worries about the uncontrollable then focus on redirecting your attention to the here and now.
* Learning about mindfulness is a helpful way to build your ability to choose where you focus your attention. A worry about the future or a painful memory may still pop up. But you get to choose whether you stay with it and churn it over, or whether you let it go and come back to the present moment.

What helps you to turn the dial down on overthinking?

Want some tips for overthinking? See below. 
The tendency to overthink, worry or overanalyse everything can often be related to high levels of anxiety. So addressing that anxiety can have a significant benefit. Start with the simplest things:
* Make extra effort to get enough sleep and get up around the same time each morning.
* Try to address any sugar level imbalances with the help of a dietitian if need be.
* Add in more movement. Exercise helps so find something you might enjoy and do it as often as you can.
* Talk. Sharing some of the things we are worried about can help to quite quickly provide us with an alternative perspective. That is because the friend we talk to may be able to fact check some of our catastrophic thinking. But they also may just share their own ideas, which gives you the chance to see the anxious perspective as just one possible narrative.

* For tips on diffusing from anxious thoughts and letting them go, or thought challenging exercises that are often used in therapy, I cover these in depth in my new book. See link in bio to order yours.

When we feel painful emotion the most natural human response is to pull away, escape and avoid. We block them out with anything that feels safe or pleasurable. But when we do that, the painful emotions don’t always disappear forever. We find ourselves trapped in cycles of addictive behaviours that keep the emotion at bay for just a short time. 

The way we guide people to process painful emotion in therapy is to allow the emotion to be there, turn towards it and feel it, while soothing yourself through the process with skills that help you to tolerate the distress. This enables the emotion to take its natural course and wash over you. Emotions come in waves so we know they will increase in intensity, peak and then come back down again. 

How do you manage painful emotion?

High functioning anxiety is not a clinical diagnosis. It is a term that people often use to describe living with high levels of anxiety while continuing to function in most areas of their life. The wide use of the term may be a reflection of the vast numbers of people who struggle to manage anxiety in everyday life. There are simple ways we can learn to manage anxiety so that we can focus on the things that matter most to us. 

My new book is stacked full with the insights from therapy and tips that we can all use to tackle anxiety. See link in bio to pre-order.

When does the mental filter come up for you? 

The mental filter is a common thought bias that happens to us all and has the potential to make us feel much worse. So any time you notice that you are holding onto thoughts that focus on threat and loss like this, don’t let it go unchecked. Notice the bias, label it and take time to consciously consider the other information available to you. These simple tools can be really effective if we put in a bit of practice and use them regularly. Give it a try and let me know what you notice. 

If you would like more details on how thought biases are making you feel worse and what you can do about it, I cover this in my book. See link in bio to order for UK, USA, and Europe. 

 I think these simple skills should be available to everyone to enhance their well-being so feel free to share / repost with friends or check out my profile @drjulie for more videos like this.

Don’t try this at home  Which signs do you come across most? Gaslighting is when one person tries to convince another person that they are wrong even when they are not. Many of us have done this mildly once in a while, but gaslighting becomes more serious when it becomes persistent and extreme. It then becomes dangerous because it starts to erode your sense of self-belief and confidence. It can even cause people to question their own sanity. 

When this starts to happen it can have a huge impact on mental health. So, for anyone who thinks they may be experiencing gaslighting it is essential to start prioritising your mental health. Below are a few tips:
* Keep a private journal. When someone persistently questions your memory or judgement, it helps to have something to refer back to. Write things down, take more photos.
* Talk to people you trust. If you only have one person to consult with and that person is gaslighting then it can be hard to consider other perspectives. Keep talking to friends.
* Speak to a therapist. Not only is this a regular conversation with someone that you trust in complete privacy, but a professional will be able to help you find new ways to respond to the gaslighting and help you find local support to leave an abusive relationship safely if necessary.

Notice my scary face at the beginning of this? Alice in Wonderland Syndrome (AWS), also known as Todd's syndrome is a frightening condition in which your visual perception is altered. It can cause objects to appear smaller, bigger, closer, or farther away than they really are. Some people seem to report similar sensations when they have been physically unwell or when they were growing up.

It is not often talked about so this might be useful and might help someone to speak up about their experiences. Always speak to a medical professional for advice.

Building confidence takes courage. If we feel fear and move forward toward what matters most to us, that is courage. But courage doesn’t mean you have to face every fear you’ve ever had or put yourself in danger just for the sake of it. It means doing what it takes to live in line with your values and the kind of person you want to be, even when doing so is more difficult than the alternative. 

What do you say no to out of fear? What does it cost you? Not in money but in being able to live in line with the sort of person you want to be. 

To build confidence, embrace that fear, take it with you. Be willing to go where you don’t feel confident and stay there until you do.

Burnout has been researched in the context of the workplace. But I have seen the same problems occur beyond the scope of paid employment. For example, people who take on caring roles for loved ones are vulnerable to the emotional exhaustion seen in burnout. 

Burnout happens when the demands placed on you have far exceeded what you are able to fulfill for a long period. This leaves you feeling emotionally drained, physically exhausted and run down. It can start to affect your mental health, physical health and relationships and needs to be addressed as soon as possible. 

What are your top habits for preventing burnout?

You don’t have to set any New Year resolutions but if the new year tends to be the time that you set new goals or projects for yourself, here is what the science says about willpower and how to make those new changes stick:

• Our ability to force ourselves to do things we hate is limited.
• When setting any goal make sure it is based on what matters to you, not what you see others doing or think you should do. 
• Be clear on why you are doing it. Write down why it is so important to you and keep coming back to it.
•When you hit hurdles or get off track (which you will) respond to that with compassion and honesty, not criticism and self-loathing. Failure is a normal part of change, not an indication of personality faults. Change is hard because you’re human. 
• If you can nurture your ability to control your attention and actions you increase chances of sustaining change. 
• Enough sleep is essential for your brain to exercise control rather than act on impulse. So switch your phone off and go to bed.
• Your brain also needs enough good quality food and water for optimal functioning and self-control improves after a healthy meal.
• Meditation improves self-control and enables you to improve the skill of choosing where to focus your attention.
• Focus on what you will do, rather than what you won’t do.
• Slow breathing calms the stress response which improves self-control and reduces impulsivity.
• Exercise also improves self-control and general health behaviours. It restores energy and willpower rather than depleting it as you might think.

For more in-depth help with personal change and growth check out my book, Why Has Nobody Told Me This Before? Link is in bio for UK, USA and European orders.

???Who can relate? If you live in England then the word sorry is something you hear on a daily basis as you go about your life. It can be considered good manners in a variety of situations. But when apologising is driven by more than just cultural habits it can be linked to low self-esteem, shame and trauma.

So look out for those apologies today. Notice the impact they have on how you feel. Also notice what feelings come up if you try resisting an unnecessary apology. This can help us to understand what’s going on in more depth. 

Stopping all the unnecessary apologies won’t fix low self-esteem by itself. But it will help. Changing these small behaviours is a significant piece of the larger puzzle.

?? Who can relate? You can talk for hours to friends but the idea of going to therapy fills you with fear. If that is you, here are a few tips from me, a psychologist who has supported countless people through that first therapy session:
• The majority of people walk into their first session feeling nervous and unsure how to articulate everything they want to say. The majority of people then walk out feeling calmer and more hopeful and inspired for their therapy journey.
• The therapy room often becomes your sanctuary. The one place you can go to and express yourself unapologetically, knowing you will not be judged. 
• It’s normal to worry that your story may shock the therapist. But it’s almost impossible to shock a therapist. 
• You cannot cover everything in the first session. Your therapist does not need you to explain everything in a specific order or with absolute clarity. They will take notes if they might need to come back to something later.
• If you feel nervous or fear judgement, say it. Tell the therapist how you feel and they will help you to understand and work through it. That is what they are there for.
• Take all your fears with you and see if therapy could help you change your life. I’m rooting for you!

Which signs have you spotted? Sometimes it’s hard to put your finger on what is going on when someone is being passive aggressive. You start questioning your every move and wonder whether you have done something wrong and what it could be. 

But passive aggression is a sign that the other person is not taking responsibility for their own role in the relationship. If they feel hurt or upset by something you have done, a healthy response would be to tell you so that you can work together to resolve things.

ad| @SanctuarySpa have identified a worrying trend in our society where so many of us neglect our own needs, work ourselves into the ground and then put in just enough self-care to pick ourselves back up only to start the cycle again.

A national survey conducted by @sanctuaryspa found that a staggering 94% of UK women have felt the benefits of taking time out to look after their wellbeing and recognise that around 50 minutes a day would be ideal. But the majority of women are only spending an average of 17 minutes a day on themselves. So we have a national self-care gap.

What do we do about it? We can't all go for a massage every day or fit in a yoga class while getting the kids ready for school. We need something that is small enough to realistically fit into our busy lives and big enough to make a difference over time.

In the same way that we aim for our five a day to keep up our fruit and veg intake, I challenge you to 25 a day. Make 25 minutes of protected time every day to do more of the things that nurture and enhance your wellbeing. For some that might be finding a quiet place to rest and recharge. For others it might be walking in nature. Self-care is any action that nurtures your own health and wellbeing.

My 25 a day is going to start with movement, as I have been sitting at the desk far too much recently. What will it be for you? Share with me in the comments how you plan to look after yourself today?

Everyone says “change how you think to change how you feel”. But to change how you feel you don’t have to change your thoughts. You can change your relationship to them. 

We can’t stop certain thoughts from arriving so we need to focus on how we respond to them. The thoughts we have are heavily influenced by our emotional state, physical state, history and what is going on around us. So the power of each thought is in how much we believe it to be a true reflection of reality. 

If your thoughts are causing you distress, it makes sense to check out why. You can learn to do this with a therapist. But you can also do this using a self-help approach. Love to here from you on this.

My book “Why has no one told me this before?”gives more detail on how to change your relationship with your thoughts, see link in my bio to order.

Which roles do you tend to take on? The drama triangle maps the destructive and shifting roles we can get into when in conflict. When each person involved is stuck in one of these roles things can keep going because there is a psychological payoff for each role. They may get their own psychological needs met without having to take responsibility for the harm done to others. By becoming aware of such patterns we can choose to make new, healthier choices in the future.
Interested to know more about this subject? Let me know in the comments. 

This theory was developed by Stephen Karpman and has been used in a model of therapy called transactional analysis.

??? For anyone who is trying to tackle anxiety but doesn’t know where to start I have put a few tips below. I also cover this subject in detail in my book. See link in bio to order for UK, USA, or Europe. 

Golden rules for tackling anxiety:
• You don’t have to start with something overwhelming. Pick something that feels challenging but manageable.
• If you can stay in the feared situation for as long as possible your body will habituate to your environment and calm over time.
• During that time use self-soothing skills to help you through it. 
• The more you repeat a behaviour the more it becomes part of your comfort zone. 
• Allow fear to be with you. Don’t push it away.
• Avoidance is the number one thing that feeds anxiety and makes it worse over time. So if there is something that you want to master but it makes you anxious, do it as often as you possibly can.
• Learn how to use basic skills to calm the mind through the body (see book for detailed description of this).

What is that thing you have been avoiding because it makes you anxious?

If you experience anxiety all that says about you is you are a human being in a tough world. I have listed below lots of quick tips from the science and the therapy room on what helps.

• Slow breathing is the quickest way to calm the body. Try to make your outbreath longer than the inbreath. Do this for several minutes.
• Exercise helps the body become more resilient to stress.
• Exercise in a green space is even more effective for improving mental health.
• Talking and listening to others helps us get new perspectives on thoughts that are causing anxiety.
• Social support on a regular basis improves outcomes for our mental health.
• Avoidance feeds anxiety and makes it worse - even though it makes you feel relief in the short term. Face things gradually but frequently.
• Use non-sleep deep relaxation or progressive muscle relaxation to calm the body and mind.
• Look out for thought biases like catastrophising. These make anxiety worse.
• Once you spot catastrophising, label those thoughts. This helps reduce their effect on us.
• Sleep well and eat well. If you don’t have enough rest or nutrition your body and mind will never be at their best.
• Visit a therapist. There are lots of evidence-based therapies that help people every day. 

For more in-depth tools on how to beat anxiety, my book covers a whole range of techniques. To order see link in bio

?Do you have a growth mindset? ??? The research conducted by Stanford psychologist Carol Dweck looked into the profound impact that certain beliefs can have on our lives. 

More specifically, she noticed that those who believe their personality, intelligence and creative abilities to be fixed from birth and unchanging (fixed mindset) were more likely to give up in the face of setbacks, ignore useful feedback, feel threatened by the success of others and avoid challenges that could lead to failure. 

Dweck found that those who set themselves up with a growth mindset (seeing failure not as a sign of permanent lack of ability but a chance for learning and growth) were more likely to persist after a setback, embrace big challenges, learn from criticism and find inspiration in others. 
I often revisit this research as I find it so helpful in my own life to set myself up with a growth mindset when I tackle big things or face setbacks. Definitely check out Dweck’s work!

In my next reel I describe how to break this cycle. But understanding how we get stuck in cycles of depression is too important to skip. Nobody chooses depression, but every choice we make, big and small, either contributes to our health or challenges it. Once we are stuck in an episode of depression we are more vulnerable to repeat behaviours that keep us stuck in the long term. This is because depression is painful, producing strong urges to find immediate relief. The things that offer immediate relief keep us stuck in the long term. They maintain depression and feed it, making it worse over time. 

It is very easy to say, “do the stuff that is good for you, even when depression tells you not to” and really hard to do it in real life. So start small. Start manageable. Pick one thing that you know will help in your recovery and double down on it. Don’t underestimate the power of the simple things. Exercise and nutrition are two examples of powerful tools when it comes to tackling depression. Those things can lift mood just enough that you then feel more able to engage in psychological therapies if that is on your agenda.

Reels are too short to do this justice but I go into much more detail on this in my new book. To pre-order see link in bio.

Can you recognise passsive aggressive behaviour when you see it?

Direct confrontation is not the only way people express negative feelings. When there is a disconnect between what someone says and what he or she does, we start to get that uncomfortable feeling that something is not right. The guessing game begins about how that person really feels. 

Some signs of passive aggressive behaviour can be:

• They may appear to agree but then fail to do what they have agreed on.
• They may frequently complain about feeling unappreciated.
• They may express a cynical or hostile attitude 

What signs of passive aggressive behaviour do you pick up on most easily?

Which train are you on? Getting to where you want to go is going to mean sitting with some discomfort along the way. But when we get comfortable our energy and motivation to face that discomfort seems to disappear. So we wait. We wait until we feel like moving out of this comfort zone, which of course we never do. 

So if you have a goal that has been on your mind for years but you just don’t feel like starting yet, why not start today? Start by shifting the focus of your attention from how you want to feel now, to how you want to feel later. All along the way keep reminding yourself, that the discomfort is temporary, and it’s part of the process. Be willing to step into the discomfort and start moving toward your goals. 

How are you going to step outside of that comfort zone this week?

It’s very easy for someone to say that, if a relationship doesn’t work for you, just end it. The reality of that is much harder, especially if those difficult relationships are with your family, spouse or other loved ones. You don’t want to end the relationship altogether, but you recognise that it is causing you emotional pain or even damaging your mental health.

In those situations, putting in some boundaries can help to improve the relationship and your own wellbeing. If setting boundaries in relationships is a new thing for you then therapists can be hugely helpful for this. The task is to carefully work out what boundaries will help you to sustain the relationship without it damaging your mental health. For some, that might be setting rules around how often you see them or how much time you spend together. For others it may be practicing the art of saying no. It can be a real struggle to be assertive or express our own needs in relationships in which we feel a sense of duty. So taking time to get clarity on the relationship in therapy can be life changing.

(BTS on my stories)  My Kintsugi bowl has become an important piece in my therapy room. It reminds me that, no matter how tough things get and how broken we can feel at times, healing can happen. It reminds me that healing is not about pretending the worst never happened. By doing the work to heal, we can find new learning, new strength and new meaning from the hardest of seasons. 

More and more, I see courageous people online sharing their stories of recovery from hardship with the aim of helping others. To me, this is Kintsugi in practice. The more these difficult conversations happen, the more we learn as a society that psychological injury is a part of life. The more we learn that it can be a pivotal part of the story, but doesn’t have to be the end of the story. With healing and recovery we can find new beauty and meaning in life. 

In addition to this, if we can recover once, we can recover again. It gives us all hope that, even when it feel like everything is in pieces, we can get there.

There are countless different reasons why many people don’t seek out the help they need or may struggle to access it. But the figures suggest we all need to do more. We need to have compassionate conversations about mental health that teach anyone who may be listening that it’s ok to talk about it. We all need to give mental health the same respect that we give to physical health. We also need to increase funding to services that are already doing a great job at providing help. We also need to share education about how we can all take responsibility for our mental health in the same way that we do for our physical health, so that we can put in place preventative measures that help us to stay well and reduce the risk of becoming unwell.

Big changes demand big adjustment which can make them hard to sustain. If you focus on starting small but staying consistent with those small changes, they add up over time. When that small change is repeated enough times it becomes a habit that no longer requires that extra will power to make it happen. Then you can move onto the next small change. 

This example of a flight shifting direction is covered by a few texts on habits, including Atomic Habits by James Clear. I will share in my stories this week some of my favourite books on habit change.

I see so much misinformation on social media about how everyone apparently has the ability to reach their full potential and happiness is no more than a choice. But that presumes that everyone has their basic human needs met.

Back in 1943, American psychologist Abraham Maslow first put forward his theory of the ‘hierarchy of needs’ - the idea that we must meet our most basic needs first, before we can seek our “higher” needs, which enable us to reach our full potential. This is an old model and others have built upon this since, but it continues to be a classic.

His theory was informed by his study of exceptional people such as Albert Einstein. He suggested that Einstein is an example of the healthiest human psychology. 

But, the self-help industry that often claims to sell lifelong happiness, does not account for the fact that you can have any of the bottom 4 layers of the hierarchy pulled like a rug from beneath you at any point. Then a process of rebuilding must begin, before you can feel safe enough and free enough to focus on fulfilling those higher potentials. 

So if you are not there yet, it is not a failure. It means you have needs that are not yet being met. Or maybe the pyramid is out of balance, with too much emphasis on one of the higher needs before you have your basic health and security sorted. It is a process of meeting each of your deepest needs so that you can move on and gradually reach your full potential.

(bloopers on my stories) Who can relate to that tug of war situation? This is a metaphor often used in Acceptance and Committment Therapy (ACT) to help describe how our attempts to control problems often become the problem. The same goes for emotion. We cannot completely control our emotional experience. But trying to control it can bring us a world of problems. By allowing all emotions to be present, we free ourselves up to understand them and then to use our energy for turning towards the things that matter most in our lives.

(Bloopers on my stories) When life throws curve ball after curve ball, you can quickly feel like you are overflowing with stress. If you want to feel less overwhelmed, there are some simple things you can do that help to release stress, leaving you feeling stronger to face the challenges in front of you.

Some of the most effective stress relievers are the first ones we let slide when we’re not feeling good. But those are the things that help us to maintain some wellbeing in tough times. Whether it be exercise, time with friends, meditation or creative hobbies, these activities are often seen as indulgent. They are, in fact, essential for helping to prevent overwhelm and burnout. 

In therapy, I often ask people to identify which activities help them to feel revitalised the most. Then we create a short list of non-negotiables. The non-negotiables are the actions that need to happen on a regular basis to maintain good mental health. There are certain behaviours that we always make time for because we perceive them as essential for good health, such as brushing our teeth. But when it comes to behaviours that nurture our mental health, our perception of them as indulgent, means they get left off the list when we are busy. What will you put on your list of non-negotiables?

??Who can relate?
Do you know where your people pleasing patterns came from? 
How do they make like easier? And how do they make life harder? What does it cost you to always be focused on keeping everybody else happy? 

The antidote to people pleasing is not selfishness. It’s balance and compromise. It’s finding ways to look after you while also maintaining your relationships. It’s not putting yourself first over everyone and everything. It’s bringing yourself up to an equal standing as your loved ones and being there for yourself in the way you are with them.

Ad| I’m proud to be supporting this mission with @acaioutdoorwear to inspire more women to get outdoors.  It shouldn’t be a once-in-a-while treat, but a staple part of our daily routine. We don’t have to climb mountains or hike through jungles to get the benefits of being outdoors. We can take a walk with a friend, hop off the bus a few stops early, or try a new route. If we can combine that with some form of green space on a regular basis it can have a significant impact on many aspects of our health and wellbeing. Time in nature reduces the levels of stress hormones in your body, calms anxiety and lifts your mood. When we combine it with exercise it builds our resilience to stress and makes us more sensitive to feelings of joy and pleasure.

Research shows us that at least 20 minutes in nature each week is associated with good health and wellbeing. But don’t stop there. The benefits seem to peak at between three to five hours outside. So I challenge you to find a way to spend more time outdoors today, tomorrow and the next day.

How will you add into your routine some more time to be outdoors this week?

Research has even shown that psychological therapies provided in a garden are even more effective than those provided in a hospital setting.

Life is messy. This means problems are rarely separate and disconnected from the different areas of our lives. They are often woven into lots of different relationships and scenarios that make it difficult to sustain positive change. 

Let’s say you developed a problematic relationship with alcohol and you wanted to stop drinking. It is likely to be an overwhelming change to make if the focus is purely on the alcohol. Problematic drinking may be wrapped up in specific social circles or a work culture, or a coping strategy for an unresolved trauma. Spending time on each of those connected problems can help to make progress more sustainable. 

Have you ever started working on other things only to find it helps you with making progress on your original goal?

You don’t need to be fearless and stress-free to be confident. Plenty of people that you may admire for their confidence will feel some fear or anxiety and definitely some stress when they face challenges. That is because the human brain is providing us with the stress response to help us perform and stay alert. Or maybe fear is helping us to avoid something that might be harmful along the way. You can feel all of that and still feel confident that you will give something your all.
You can still feel confident that you are doing the right thing.
You can still feel confident that whatever the outcome, you will have your own back and dust yourself off ready to try again at this thing that matters to you.

There are things that can give us almost instant relief from anxiety. But those things tend to keep us stuck in the long term. 

Let’s say you’re in a supermarket and you start to feel the pounding heart and sweaty palms. You recognise this to be anxiety and the urge is to get out of there as quickly as you can. When you do the anxiety subsides and you feel a sense of relief that you have decided not to face it today. 

That relief may last until the next time you need to go back to the supermarket. When you do, the anxiety response might be even worse because escaping the situation before your body had a chance to calm has reinforced the association your brain makes between the supermarket and danger. Your brain never got the chance to experience remaining in the supermarket and calming over time. 

What situations trigger anxiety for you and that urge to escape?

Treating others how you want to be treated is always advisable. But something that original advice misses out, is how we treat ourselves. The boundaries we set and keep for ourselves communicate to others what is acceptable and what is not. This can be incredibly hard to do if we have been taught to diminish our own needs in favour of everyone else’s.

Many people show great compassion to others but don’t include themselves. Many people do not see themselves as worthy of receiving such kindness. Or perhaps they accept disrespect from others as they do not feel deserving of anything more. 

Why not try it today? Treating yourself with the same love, care and respect that you give to others? Let me know how it goes!

Signs of depression can be complex and vary between people. Fluctuation in mood and general wellbeing is normal but if symptoms persist for weeks or months they can start to interfere with your relationships or ability to function and connect with others.

You can find more videos  @drjuliesmith 

 I have listed below some of the psychological symptoms of depression:

- [ ] Continuous low mood or sadness
- [ ] Feeling hopeless and helpless
- [ ] Low self-esteem
- [ ] Feeling tearful
- [ ] Feeling guilt-ridden
- [ ] Feeling irritable and intolerant of others
- [ ] Having no motivation or losing interest in things you used to enjoy
- [ ] Difficulty making decisions
- [ ] Feeling anxious or worried
- [ ] Rumination 
- [ ] Avoiding contact with friends

Physical symptoms include:
- [ ] Sleep disturbance 
- [ ] Appetite changes
- [ ] Low libido
- [ ] Unexpected aches and pains
- [ ] Low energy

If you are ever concerned about your mental health, seek professional support.

???Your self-concept is created, not just from how you see yourself, or what others think of you, but what you think others think of you*. 

Our own ideas about how we are perceived by others used to involve a lot of guess work, but for many taking part in the online world it is clear that people express fleeting negative judgments and verbal attack in a way that they wouldn’t in a person to person conversation. So anyone expressing themselves online is more vulnerable to negative judgment. 

In addition to that, the colossal explosion in both highly filtered, face and body distorting images and the fierce marketing of cosmetic surgery and fillers to create such a familiarity that they all appear to be a part of ‘normal’ life, the following stats that are popping up in research start to make sense:

• over 1/3 teenagers felt upset and ashamed in relation to their body image.
•over 1/3 adults reported feeling depressed because of their body image.
• 19% of adults say they feel disgusted by their appearance.

One caption is not enough to break down the complex issues surrounding this. But one way that we can all play our part is to remember that behind every post online is a real human being. 

If you wouldn’t have it written on your t-shirt, don’t write it online. 

Do you feel that your perception of yourself or your appearance has been influenced by the online world?

*See the work of Charles Cooley.

Do you ever fall into that “all or nothing” trap. Black and white thinking is a cognitive bias that we all do at times, but we tend to do more of it when we are stressed. Something small happens and, “the whole day is ruined!” 

This tendency to think in absolutes can make it harder to deal with hurdles because it triggers more intense emotional reactions. If we can only consider something a complete success or a complete failure then we are vulnerable to feeling like a complete failure much of the time. 

So look out for that all or nothing/ black or white thinking. When you notice it appear, call it out. Acknowledge it is a bias that is not helpful. The process of recognising the bias for what it is, will help to take some of the power out of it. Then you can consider alternative perspectives. Give it a go ??

The reason I have a slight grin on my face at the beginning of this video is because I had burnt my fingers in the previous take and was wondering how quickly I could say the words 

We all get overworked and tired every now and then but burnout is more than tiredness. Burnout is when stress becomes chronic and has a detrimental effect on other areas in your life. 
Signs of burnout include chronic exhaustion alongside restlessness and trouble sleeping, poor self-care such as diet and exercise. Other signs include repeated emotional distress, such as anxiety, low mood, or anger outbursts. You may notice your performance at work is going down, while you feel you are working harder than ever, you may also start feeling disconnected with loved ones and struggle to get along as well as you normally do.
If burnout is on the horizon, here are a few things we can do to put on the breaks. 

•Start working out what you can say no to. Often we feel obliged to say yes to every request or opportunity. When our health is in question, it’s a pretty good reason to practice the art of saying no to things that are not an absolute priority.

•Prioritise self-care. Get back to basics because they are the foundations of good mental and physical health. Make sleep, healthy food, hydration, exercise and social time top of your to do list. And don’t underestimate the power of these things to build your resilience.

• Re-think what matters. We are vulnerable to burnout when we are working hard on something that is not in line with our own values. Taking time to think through how you want your life to be, the kind of person you want to be, or the impact you want to have on the world can help to get clarity on how to redirect your life in a way that suits you.

• Get support. If you are worried about your mental health in any way, seeking support from a trusted friend or a professional is one of the best things you can do and your chances of making a full recovery greatly improve. Human connection is a powerful tool. Use it.

Our brain is set up to detect signs of threat and danger. It is able to do that so fast that it can set off a series of biological responses in your body before you have even had a chance to think through what is happening. That is function is not an out of date brain system left over from the past. It still keeps you alive today. But the speed of that response means that it can fire off when there are signs of danger but no real danger. It is then up to us to use our conscious mind to think through our situation and decide whether those signs warrant a threat response or whether to get to work calming the body back down to baseline. 

What situations trigger your threat response that turn out to be the burning toast rather than a real fire?

???Making change is so hard because we don’t always feel like it. In a therapy called dialectical Behaviour Therapy (DBT) we teach the skill of opposite action. This involves making a conscious effort to notice urges and to recognise that we don’t always have to act in line with those urges. We can make a choice to act opposite to the urge. It is far from easy in some circumstances but life changing when it is well-practiced to the advantage of your health and best interests. 

The opposite action is helping for harmful behaviours but also for other things like getting back into the swing of things with regular exercise or building your social contact back up again after being isolated through the pandemic, or getting that piece of work done that has been put off for too long. 

You can practice with small things like holding a mint in your mouth and going against the urge to crunch it. Simple exercises like that can help us to open up to the possibility of acting based on what we want rather than we we feel. 

When are you great at acting opposite and when do you find it more difficult?

??? So did you notice that it took more time and conscious effort to name the colour when it did not match the word? If you did then this is know as the Stroop effect.

This short clip comes from the longer Stroop test that was originally designed by John Stroop in 1935. 
It was taught as one of the classic psychology experiments back in my undergraduate days and I’m sharing it with you as just one example of how amazing your brain is.

So what is happening? The Stroop effect demonstrates something called cognitive interference. You experience a delayed reaction because the information about the colour of the print and the word does not match up. 
How is this useful? This test can be combined with others to measure a person’s selective attention capacity and their processing speed ability. 
Here are two theories about why it happens:
The theory of automaticity suggests that recognising and labelling colours is not an automatic process so it takes time and conscious effort (maybe because you don’t often need to do this). The brain automatically understands the meaning of words because it is so well practiced at it.

Another theory is selective attention theory. This suggests that colour recognition requires more attention than reading a word, so it takes longer.

If you are feeling overwhelmed with distress, splashing ice cold water on your face (also know as ice diving) can help to reduce your heart rate while at the same time providing a strong anchor for your grounding technique. This simply means, those strong physical sensations help to bring your attention to the here and now. So, if you tend to get overwhelmed, stock up on ice and give it a try.

??? The research conducted by Stanford psychologist Carol Dweck looked into the profound impact that certain beliefs can have on our lives. 

More specifically, she noticed that those who believe their personality, intelligence and creative abilities to be fixed from birth and unchanging (fixed mindset) were more likely to give up in the face of setbacks, ignore useful feedback, feel threatened by the success of others and avoid challenges that could lead to failure. 

Dweck found that those who set themselves up with a growth mindset (seeing failure not as a sign of permanent lack of ability but a chance for learning and growth) were more likely to persist after a setback, embrace big challenges, learn from criticism and find inspiration in others. 
I often revisit this research as I find it so helpful in my own life to set myself up with a growth mindset when I tackle big things or face setbacks. Definitely check out Dweck’s work! 

#growthmindset #fixedmindset #psychology #psychologist #success #failure #mentalhealth #therapist #motivation

“TROLLS” and “HATERS” have become the terms used for people who verbally abuse or attack others on social media and the big question is “why?” Why would one person do that to another online when it doesn’t seem to happen in the streets? The complete answer may not be a simple one but decades before the internet arrived Zimbardo was conducting experiments like the one I described in this video and demonstrating the ease with which ordinary people can be led to engage in anti-social behaviour by putting them in situations where they felt anonymous or in which they could perceive others as objects or less than human. 

What are your thoughts? Have you ever behaved online in a way that you later regretted? What do you think contributes to this sort of behaviour? 

While the prison experiment was criticised for its methodology, there is much more literature on this subject. It seems the scenario has changed, but humans remain the same.

The physical signs of anxiety are very similar to those of excitement because both signal the body gearing up in anticipation of action. But when we conceptualise those physical feelings as excitement we are more likely to feel that we can tolerate them and move forward through the challenge. When we frame those physical sensations as anxiety we are more likely to do the opposite. This is why reframing can be such a helpful strategy for managing challenges that could be perceived in either way. If you can steer your attention toward the aspects of the challenge that you can feel excited about, you will experience the benefits of excitement over anxiety. Interestingly the sensations of anxiety don’t disappear. We shift our perspective of them so that we can use them to our advantage.

Catastrophising is a thought bias that happens to everyone. When your stress response is triggered, your brain is set up to look for danger. It tries to make sense of the information it has by making predictions for you so that you can do whatever is necessary to stay safe. 

When we are truly in a dangerous situation, this is an incredible survival response. But in today’s society, our stress responses are triggered repeatedly, in situations that are not life or death. So, when we start catastrophising, it is not followed up with action, and we are left with lots of worry thoughts churning over in our minds. 

When we spend time focusing on worst case scenarios, it re-triggers the stress response and our anxiety increases.

So how do we deal with catastrophising? First, we must begin to spot them. Maybe start by noting down at the end of the day, any catastophising thoughts that came up today. In time, you will be able to notice them in the moment, as they happen.

Secondly, when you notice that your thoughts are jumping to the worst case scenario, call it out. Label that thought as a catastrophising thought. A thought bias. 

Simply acknowledging the thought as a bias can sometimes be enough to help us recognise that there are alternative perspectives available, and thinking the worst does not mean the worst will happen.

???These are just some of the many physical signs of anxiety. The tricky part is that signs of anxiety can also be signs of something purely physical. For example, if you notice your heart pounding it could be a sign that you’ve had too much caffeine. If you feel shaky and trembly it could be dehydration. Always check in with the possibility that there could be a simple physical cause and keep up with the basics like sleep, hydration, healthy food and social connection. They may seem simple but there impact is not small.

Spending lots of time ruminating about the past is a key factor for maintaining depression and low mood. 

Spending lots of time focusing on the future can make us anxious. But it’s not only thinking about the future that triggers anxiety. It’s trying to control that future. 

Learning to sit with uncertainty is a key skill in managing anxiety. Something that enables us to do that is building self-compassion. The two may not seem to go together. But when you learn to keep promises to yourself, always have your own back and act with your own best interests at heart, then it becomes easier.  You begin to trust that, no matter what happens, you will do the best by yourself and get through.

There are simple ways we can learn to manage anxiety so that we can focus on the things that matter most to us.

??? Anxiety tells us to escape and avoid. That makes sense if we are truly in danger. If we are not in a survival situation and the thing you fear means something to you and the life you want to live, then do it as much as possible. 

Whether it be learning to dance, joining that art class having never before picked up a paint brush, going to a party and challenging yourself to talk to someone new. If fear is holding you back from doing something that would enhance your life, take baby steps at first, and just start. Start today, and again tomorrow, and the next day. Keep going in achievable steps, however small, and don’t stop until it becomes part of your comfort zone ??

Who puts the phone down and immediately starts ruminating on all the things you said wrong, the things that didn’t sound the way you intended them to, and what the other person must be thinking about you? 

Social anxiety doesn’t stop the moment the interaction stops. We continue to focus on everything that we got wrong in that conversation, which further increases the anxiety and reinforces the fear response for the next interaction. 

To break that cycle, some people find it helpful to occupy your mind in the moments after an interaction to prevent the rumination from starting. Others find it helpful to practice mindfulness. But if you are new mindfulness it is best to start practicing in situations that feel easier to start with.

Worrying about what others think of us is a normal part of being human. But when it takes over our life decisions it can affect our own happiness and fulfilment in life. 

We cannot stop those worry thoughts from coming, but we can respond to them by turning back to our own values. Am I being the person that I most approve of? Am I living in line with my own values? These are questions that I use to help me come back to me and keep the judgments of others in perspective.

Anyone with an anxious attachment style may struggle to feel secure in relationships. Our attachment styles are laid down early in life and can influence the way we function in our adult relationships. 

Attachment can’t explain everything that occurs in relationships but it can help us to make sense of some patterns of behaviour that we might feel stuck in. 

This is just a 15 second intro to a much bigger subject area, so if you’d like some longer videos on this, let me know in the comments.

Thoughts can cause so much distress. The power of any thought is in how much we buy into it as meaningful truth or fact. 

So if your thoughts are causing you distress, it makes sense to check out just how much we should believe in the thought. We can do this with a few different methods:

1. Thought challenging: this is where you put the thought to the test. List out the evidence for and against that thought being fact. Sometimes this can be enough to loosen off your belief in a thought that may have been biased. If this process leads to internal arguments with yourself about whether a thought is fact, then try the next method.

2. Practice being mindful of the thoughts. Observe them rather than getting caught up in it. Notice it’s effect on you. View it as an experience washing over you, rather than a part of you. Acknowledge that this is one version of reality, one idea, one theory. Then come back to the here and now. If doing this is difficult it can be helpful to write the thoughts down. This is called thought defusion, which means getting instuck from a thought so that it has less power of you and your actions. 

If you find these difficult to do alone you can get a therapist to support you.

#thoughts #anxiety #mentalhealth #mentalhealthawareness #selfhealers #selfhelp #therapy #therapist #anxietytips su22259k

The primacy effect impacts the way we make decisions. Our opinions can be more easily skewed than we think because we show a cognitive bias toward first impressions. The first time we get information about something is more easily recalled than what comes later. This is used by advertising agencies to manipulate decisions about product choice and by filmmakers who release trailers long before anyone has the chance to review the movie. 

But you can also use the primacy effect to your advantage. For example, if you have a job interview, always choose the first interview slot of the day if you want to be remembered and think carefully about what the information you want them to remember. Try to get that in first. Or last - that is the recency effect, but that’s a whole other video! 

#psychology #science #sciencefacts #psychologist #lifetips #selfhelp #trythis #challenge #psychologyfacts w1940

While the story of this incident later came into question about whether it happened and how many people were present, crucially it started a surge of research in this area of study.

Maybe we never truly know for sure how we would react in a difficult situation, but would you like to help someone in need if you came across them? If you think you might hold back, what might cause that hesitation? 

Since studies began on the bystander effect many researchers have pointed out that we often see exceptions to that rule in which people step in to help, even putting their own safety at risk.

Something people learn in therapy is that thoughts are not facts. We know this because they are influenced by so many factors, including our emotions, physical state, and actions. 

The reason that many people find this life changing is that when a pattern of thinking is causing us distress, we don’t have to be at the mercy of it. 

We can choose to step back from those thoughts and see them for what they are; a mix of judgments, ideas, theories, opinions and stories. 

When we do this, it can take some of the power out of those thoughts because we have some choice about how much we buy into the idea as a fact, how much time we spend focussing on it, and whether we acknowledge other alternative perspectives. 

We cannot suppress thoughts and stop them from arriving, but we can consciously introduce new ones that, in turn, have an impact on how we feel.

I cover this in more detail in my book. See link in bio to pre-order

When we feel painful emotion the most natural human response is to pull away, escape them and avoid. We block them out with anything that feels safe and pleasurable. But when we do that, the painful emotions don’t always disappear forever. We find ourselves trapped in cycles of addictive behaviours that keep the emotion at bay for just a short time. 

The way we guide people to process painful emotion in therapy is to allow the emotion to be there, turn towards it and feel it, while soothing yourself through the process with skills that help you to tolerate the distress. This enables the emotion to take its natural course and wash over you. Emotions come in waves so we know they will increase in intensity, peak and then come back down again.

One mistake many of us make when we have a goal we want to work on, is waiting until we feel like it. We wait to feel this elusive thing called motivation. 

But here’s the thing about motivation. It doesn’t arrive out of nowhere. We can generate the feeling with getting clear on why we are doing something and then starting to take action towards it. Action generates energy and we can build some momentum. 

But that is not the whole story. Motivation doesn’t just arrive and then stick around. Like all other feelings, it fluctuates. The key to progressing in anything is being so clear on why you are doing it, that you can push through on those days when motivation is not there.

High functioning depression is a term used a lot across social media but it is not a clinical term or diagnosis. It is a term that has come to be used to describe the huge numbers of people who function well in everyday life but struggle with low mood and symptoms of depression. 

Anyone who suffers with symptoms of depression should seek professional help, even if they are managing to function day to day. There are a number of therapies and treatments that can help.

Procrastinating is normal. It’s not a fault of character or a clinical problem. But it can often be a sign of stress. When we avoid something it can be because we anticipate feeling something that we don’t want to feel. That might be stress, or fear, or even boredom. Procrastination can arise even more when perfectionism and a fear of failure is part of the equation. 

When we notice that we are procrastinating, reflecting on why that might be is the first crucial step to tackling it. Once we know what we are avoiding we can make a more informed choice about our actions instead of basing our actions on how we feel right now.

Burnout has been researched in the context of the workplace. But I have seen the same problems occur beyond the scope of paid employment. For example, people who take on caring roles for loved ones are vulnerable to the emotional exhaustion seen in burnout. 

Burnout happens when the demands placed on you have far exceeded what you are able to fulfill for a long period. This leaves you feeling emotionally drained, physically exhausted and run down. It can start to affect your mental health, physical health and relationships and needs to be addressed as soon as possible.

If you ever feel overwhelmed with stress or anxiety, this is an easy breathing technique that can be done anywhere. It is often called square breathing or box breathing because you can find a window or picture frame to help you focus on slowing the breath and counting in 4 seconds, hold 4 seconds, out 4 seconds and hold 4 seconds. 

Of course, if the timings don’t fit for you then you can adjust. The main aim is that you slow the breathing down. It can take several minutes so stick with it. Any time that your mind wonders, bring your attention back to counting the breath.

Some behaviour patterns are most associated with relationship breakups. 

Research suggests that contempt is the strongest predictor of divorce. 
Contempt is more than criticism. It involves attacking someone from a position of moral superiority. Contempt is when we get truly mean. We call them names, disrespect them, ridicule and roll our eyes.

Despite the research, the presence of these behaviours in your relationship does not automatically mean it will end in divorce. Becoming aware of how damaging these behaviours can be, and noticing when they occur, is the first step towards change.

Habits are everything. The self-help industry has a lot to answer for when it comes to promising people huge life transformations overnight. True change that you can sustain for a lifetime comes from changing small daily habits one at a time. You give that one small habit change your laser focus and keep getting back on track each time you return to old habits until, several months down the line, it comes as second nature without much conscious effort. Then you move onto the next one and repeat the process. Those small changes that you repeat over a sustained period of time, add up. 

If you want more on how to break bad habits and build healthier ones, let me know in the comments.

A 15 second intro to growth mindset for you. When someone is in a fixed mindset they perceive their abilities and potential to be fixed and unchangeable. In a growth mindset that person acknowledges the potential for improvement and change over time. A simple but powerful tool. Carol Dweck presents some insightful research on this. Setting yourself up with a growth mindset can improve performance and reduce the chance of giving up in response to hurdles and failure along the way. Small shifts in how you speak to yourself can be life changing because they start to influence our behaviour, performance, perseverance, and relationships.

Whatever your goals, getting into a growth mindset will help you reach them. In my experience clinically, I see how a growth mindset compliments self-compassion training to transform how people relate to themselves.

#motivation #mindset #growthmindset #selfcompassion #selfhelp #psychology #selfworth #positivemindset
