One mistake many of us make when we have a goal we want to work on, is waiting until we feel like it. We wait to feel this elusive thing called motivation. 

But here’s the thing about motivation. It doesn’t arrive out of nowhere. We can generate the feeling with getting clear on why we are doing something and then starting to take action towards it. Action generates energy and we can build some momentum. 

But that is not the whole story. Motivation doesn’t just arrive and then stick around. Like all other feelings, it fluctuates. The key to progressing in anything is being so clear on why you are doing it, that you can push through on those days when motivation is not there.

Treating others how you want to be treated is always advisable. But something that original advice misses out, is how we treat ourselves. The boundaries we set and keep for ourselves communicate to others what is acceptable and what is not. This can be incredibly hard to do if we have been taught to diminish our own needs in favour of everyone else’s.

Many people show great compassion to others but don’t include themselves. Many people do not see themselves as worthy of receiving such kindness. Or perhaps they accept disrespect from others as they do not feel deserving of anything more. 

Why not try it today? Treating yourself with the same love, care and respect that you give to others? Let me know how it goes!

Anxiety is there to help us make quick decisions in dangerous situations. When we are in danger, it’s a pretty effective survival mode that keeps us safe. When that survival mode is being triggered frequently, in situations that do not require it, we can find ourselves withdrawing from things that would otherwise be important to us. 

Life is much more satisfying when we are able to base our choices on our own personal values. This means all the things that matter to us, the kind of person you want to be, what you want your life to represent, the contribution you want to make to the world. 

Fear generally tells us to escape and avoid. But that is not always helpful if there is something you want to do with your life.

The research conducted by Stanford psychologist Carol Dweck looked into the profound impact that certain beliefs can have on our lives. 

More specifically, she noticed that those who believe their personality, intelligence and creative abilities to be fixed from birth and unchanging (fixed mindset) were more likely to give up in the face of setbacks, ignore useful feedback, feel threatened by the success of others and avoid challenges that could lead to failure. 

Dweck found that those who set themselves up with a growth mindset (seeing failure not as a sign of permanent lack of ability but a chance for learning and growth) were more likely to persist after a setback, embrace big challenges, learn from criticism and find inspiration in others. 
I often revisit this research as I find it so helpful in my own life to set myself up with a growth mindset when I tackle big things or face setbacks. Definitely check out Dweck’s work!

Like and share with others  When you feel anxious or uncomfortable around other people, it is very hard to stay present and focussed on the conversation. Your thoughts drift off to worry about how you are coming across, second guessing your every move, and imagining the other person judging you. 

This adds to the anxiety because you can lose the thread of the conversation and the cycle continues. 

For those who don’t usually experience social anxiety, this experience can easily be triggered when you have lots on your mind or you are under lots of stress in other areas of your life. 

One way to manage this is based on the research that tells us people who feel confident tend to focus on others, while people who are socially anxious tend to focus inward.  Keep bringing your mind back to a mindset of curiosity. Be curious about what the other person has to say, what they feel, or something you want to share with them or learn from them. Curiosity takes us beyond a focus on the self to a focus on others.

Like this to spread the word. Anxiety tells us to escape and avoid. That makes sense if we are truly in danger. If we are not in a survival situation and the thing you fear means something to you and the life you want to live, then do it as much as possible. 

Whether it be learning to dance, joining that art class having never before picked up a paint brush, going to a party and challenging yourself to talk to someone new. If fear is holding you back from doing something that would enhance your life, take baby steps at first, and just start. Start today, and again tomorrow, and the next day. Keep going in achievable steps, however small, and don’t stop until it becomes  part of your comfort zone.

Anyone with an anxious attachment style may struggle to feel secure in relationships. Our attachment styles are laid down early in life and can influence the way we function in our adult relationships. 

Attachment can’t explain everything that occurs in relationships but it can help us to make sense of some patterns of behaviour that we might feel stuck in.

The anxiety response is like a smoke alarm because it does not stop to work out the true cause of the warning signals it has picked up on. It just sounds the alarm. For example, you may get a rush of anxiety when you cross the road and suddenly spot a car car coming towards you at speed. This would be a useful time to get that rush of adrenaline that helps you get to the side of the road quicker than you ever thought you could move. The next day, you may get a rush of anxiety at just the thought of crossing the road again. This may be a helpful signal to take care crossing the road, but does not signal immediate and urgent danger. 

When anxiety gets triggered but we are not in danger, we have a number of options for calming the body and mind, to silence that alarm. These include, slow breathing techniques. When you slow your breathing, you limit the excess oxygen needed to fuel the anxiety response. If you would like some videos on slow breathing techniques let me know in the comments.

Other options include thought challenging, mindfulness, exercise self-soothing and relaxation techniques. For more on any of these let me know in the comments.

Just a little thought for the day, but a really important one to spend time reflecting on every now and then. 

When life gets busy, the to do list is never ending and life feels like nothing more than a daily grind, it is too easy to completely let go of the things that lift us up and make us feel energised and alive. But revisiting those things, even for a short time can do wonders in helping us to keep going. So whether it be a sport, time with friends, walking in nature, or dancing to your favourite music, whatever it is for you, put some time in the diary. Your mental health will thank you for it!

Which way did you see the dancer spin? Could you see her go in the opposite direction? An online survey of over 1600 participants showed that around two thirds of people see the rotation as clockwise. Interestingly, those people had more difficulty perceiving the opposite direction. 

This is known as the silhouette illusion, created in 2003 by Japanese web designer Nobuyuki Kayahara. 

So why does this happen? The illusion appears this way because of the lack of visual cues for depth that help us to make sense of direction.

A psychology study suggests that a viewing-from-above bias influences our perceptions of it. The silhouette is presented with a slight camera elevation. So, you can see it from above or below. The person who has a counterclockwise perception is viewing it from below the silhouette. 

Pop psychology has wrongly used this as a personality test. They suggest it tells us which side of your brain is more dominant, but that is incorrect. However, a great little test to try out on your friends! 

Depending on your perception the change of direction can happen spontaneously. If you are struggling to see the opposite direction, try the following tips:

* Avert your eyes slightly and focus on an arm or a leg. Try to visualise it going in front or behind and then move your eyes back.
* Tilt your head to help you see a change in direction
* Close your eyes and visualise the dancer going in another direction. Then open your eyes.

Another fascinating aspect to this illusion can be seen if you place it alongside a mirror. It’s not what you expect. Check it out and see what happens!

There is a misconception that depression is all about feeling sad and tearful. For some this is true, for others they cannot feel anything at all. They are numb to all emotion. They may feel like they need to cry, but tears don’t come, they don’t feel sadness, anger, joy or fear. The feel empty. When this happens, going about your daily life can feel exhausting, but time alone seems to open up a vacuum of painful nothingness. 

If you are concerned about your mental health or that of someone you know, seek help and support. Support may come in the form of a doctor, a therapist, a friend, charity or mental health team.

When learning about trauma and trying to understand how many behaviours can be understood by past traumas, I found it incredibly helpful to hear it explained in this way. Past trauma can be like having a serious burn all over your body. The slightest touch can cause extreme pain. If the person who brushed past you could not see those burns, they might judge your response as “overreacting” or “sensitive”. However, those who understand the injury will be able to make sense of the reaction.

We all get overworked and tired every now and then but burnout is more than tiredness. Burnout is when stress becomes chronic and overwhelming and has a detrimental effect on everything else in your life. 

Signs of burnout include chronic exhaustion alongside restlessness and trouble sleeping, poor self-care such as diet and exercise. Other signs include repeated emotional distress, such as anxiety, low mood, or anger outbursts. You may notice your performance at work is going down, while you feel you are working harder than ever, you may also start feeling disconnected with loved ones and struggle to get along as well as you normally do.

If burnout is on the horizon, here are a few things we can do to put on the breaks. 

•Start working out what you can say no to. Often we feel obliged to say yes to every request or opportunity. When our health is in question, it’s a pretty good reason to practice the art of saying no to things that are not an absolute priority.

•Prioritise self-care. Get back to basics because they are the foundations of good mental and physical health. Make sleep, healthy food, hydration, exercise and social time top of your to do list. And don’t underestimate the power of these things to build your resilience.

• Re-think what matters. We are vulnerable to burnout when we are working hard on something that is not in line with our own values. Taking time to think through how you want your life to be, the kind of person you want to be, or the impact you want to have on the world can help to get clarity on how to redirect your life in a way that suits you.

• Get support. If you are worried about your mental health in any way, seeking support from a trusted friend or a professional is one of the best things you can do and your chances of making a full recovery greatly improve. Human connection is a powerful tool. Use it.

People pleasing is not the same as just wanting to be kind to others. It is a pattern of behaviours that are detrimental to the health and wellbeing of the individual. 

It can be associated with anxiety about disapproval from others, fear of rejection or low self-worth. It can involve feeling unable to say no, even when the request is damaging to your own health, values or integrity. It can also lead to resentment in relationships, self-neglect and depression. 

Breaking the cycle of behaviours involves recognising the patters and the underlying cause, using assertiveness skills to say no when the situation could be damaging to your own wellbeing, and allowing yourself to receive the same kindness and compassion that you give to others.

So what is self-compassion?

Self-compassion means recognising when you are suffering and responding to that with forgiveness, kindness, encouragement and nurturing. 

Self-compassion means having your own back no matter what. It’s doing the best by yourself, even when it is the more difficult thing to do.

This is why self-compassion is distinctly different from self-indulgence. Indulgence could be doing whatever you feel like doing, taking the easy, safest or most pleasurable option. 

Self-compassion is quite often the more difficult option that is best for us in the long term. This might be making healthy food choices, saying no to relationships that are damaging to you. It might be getting yourself out of bed to make it to work, but then giving yourself a much needed rest after. 

It can also be making a conscious effort to talk to yourself with the same kindness and respect that you would give to a best friend or loved one in distress. The reason we are kind to those who are suffering is because we know it is what they need. So let’s do that for ourselves and watch our mental health improve.

None of us like to be judged by others because it hurts every time. But basing our choices on avoiding judgment and criticism from others is not a path to long lasting happiness because zero judgment is an impossible goal. Whatever you choose, there will be someone who won’t like it. So we must focus on gaining our own approval and living by our own values. When we are living in line with the things that matter most to us, then the judgments of others carry less weight, and are a little less painful.
Who else seems to spend their time trying to please others?

Self-sabotage might show up in small ways, like repeatedly choosing foods that we know do not nourish us, or bigger ways such as staying in relationships that damage our wellbeing. 

Self-sabotage is a pattern of behaviour that can be changed. Building awareness of our own patterns and coming to an understanding about any function those patterns may have served in the past can help us begin the process of change. This can be examined through self-reflection or journaling, but these are often very difficult changes to make. So seeking the support of a trusted friend or professional can be key.

Follow me for more  A 15 second intro to growth mindset for you. When someone is in a fixed mindset they perceive their abilities and potential to be fixed and unchangeable. In a growth mindset that person acknowledges the potential for improvement and change over time. A simple but powerful tool. Carol Dweck presents some insightful research on this. Setting yourself up with a growth mindset can improve performance and reduce the chance of giving up in response to hurdles and failure along the way. Small shifts in how you speak to yourself can be life changing because they start to influence our behaviour, performance, perseverance, and relationships.

Whatever your goals, getting into a growth mindset will help you reach them. In my experience clinically, I see how a growth mindset compliments self-compassion training to transform how people relate to themselves.

Many people hold the misconception that if they stop being hard on themselves they will lose their drive and ambition. This is not true. The best athletes in the world do not have coaches that call them names or verbally abuse them on the daily. They have coaches that encourage, support, guide and inspire. They have coaches who do the best for them on both good days and bad. This is because it is necessary to drive sustainable, high level performance and maintain wellbeing at the same time. 

Constant self-criticism and self-loathing is like living with a bully 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Not a good recipe for your mental health.

Something people learn in therapy is that thoughts are not facts. We know this because they are influenced by so many factors, including our emotions, physical state, and actions. 

The reason that many people find this life changing is that when a pattern of thinking is causing us distress, we don’t have to be at the mercy of it. 

We can choose to step back from those thoughts and see them for what they are; a mix of judgments, ideas, theories, opinions and stories. 

When we do this, it can take some of the power out of those thoughts because we have some choice about how much we buy into the idea as a fact, how much time we spend focussing on it, and whether we acknowledge other alternative perspectives. 

For more detail on this subject, let me know in the comments

People often talk about how your thoughts influence your emotions. But your emotions also influence your thoughts. When you feel low in mood, your are more vulnerable to negative thoughts and all the thought biases that keep the low mood going. 

This may seem simple but it is hard to recognise that bias when we are deep in the emotion. Reminding ourselves that those thoughts are a bias, the dark lens of depression, this helps us to recognise that we can choose whether to go with those thoughts or allow them to pass and consider alternative perspectives. 

All this is easy for me to say, much harder to do in practice. But practice makes progress. If it feels hard to make progress alone, then a well-qualified therapist is a great option to guide you through.

Catastrophising is a thought bias that happens to everyone. When your stress response is triggered, your brain is set up to look for danger. When it can’t immediately detect danger, your brain is wired to imagine what could happen so that you can do whatever is necessary to stay safe. 

When we are truly in a dangerous situation, this is an incredible survival response. But in today’s society, our stress responses are triggered repeatedly, in situations that are not life or death. So, when we start catastrophising, it is not followed up with action, and we are left with lots of worry thoughts churning over in our minds. 

When we spend time focusing on worst case scenarios, it re-triggers the stress response and our anxiety increases.

So how do we deal with catastrophising? First, we must begin to spot them. Maybe start by noting down at the end of the day, any catastophising thoughts that came up today. In time, you will be able to notice them in the moment, as they happen.

Secondly, when you notice that your thoughts are jumping to the worst case scenario, call it out. Label that thought as a catastrophising thought. A thought bias. 

Simply acknowledging the thought as a bias can sometimes be enough to help us recognise that there are alternative perspectives available, and thinking the worst does not mean the worst will happen.

Do you notice that when your stress levels are heightened, your mind starts to worry about all sorts of things that are completely unrelated? 
This is because your stress response signals, “all is not ok!” And so your mind starts to scan for any indication that confirms why the stress response has been activated. 
In this clip, the brain keeps coming up with new ideas for things that could lead to catastrophe, and the repeated checking is the safety behaviour that reduces the anxiety...but only for a few moments.

Learning to manage anxiety takes time but there are some simple techniques that help to reduce anxiety within just a few minutes. 

I often teach people some slow breathing techniques early in the therapy process, not only to provide some immediate relief from the distress, but also to give them a chance to experience being able to bring down the intensity of their emotion. 

Learning that you are not at the mercy of your emotions is fundamental to overcoming anxiety. Once you are equipped with a toolbox of techniques to help, there is no need to fear the fear.

Many people struggle to let go of self-criticism as they believe it gives them drive. They have, somewhere along the line, been taught that self-compassion is the same as self-indulgence. It is not. If self-criticism and self-loathing was the key to living well, we’d all be on top of the world right now.
When we are struggling, what we need most is unconditional support, encouragement and kindness. These things make individuals flourish. Whether they are coming from another person or inside our own head, they are still the best way. So have a go. Imagine what you would say to a best friend in your position. That is usually along the lines of what you need to hear the most.
#selfcompassion #mentalhealth #selfcriticism

Depression gives us the urge to do the things that give us short-term relief but keep us stuck in the long term. For example, one duvet day when you are exhausted and feeling terrible, may be just what you needed. Day after day for a week may not be so helpful in lifting your mood and recharging you. It is likely to leave you lethargic, struggling to sleep, and struggling with your mood.

When our mood is low we tend to make decisions based on how we feel at the time. This is often because how we feel is so painful. Starting to base decisions on what is best for ourselves in the long term instead of our feelings, can be an essential tool in recovery from day to day low mood or more severe depression.

The ‘Act Opposite’ skill is taught in a very specialised therapy but I think it is one of the most valuable skills for all areas of life. Being able to choose your actions based on your values and the kind of person you want to be, even when you don’t feel like it, is essential. Why? Because, no matter how important something is to you, there will be days when you don’t feel like it. Using this skill to overcome those moments is the key to persisting when things get tough and not giving up on yourself.

Please read  When I first started sharing videos about mental health I was opened up to a new level of vulnerability. I could not find another psychologist on Tiktok doing the same thing. Some videos I couldn’t watch back. Couldn’t listen to the sound of my own voice. What would my family think? What would my friends think? What would my colleagues and other psychologists think? You get the theme. Every thought that held me back had something to do with other people’s opinion of me. 

Knowing about the remedies does not make us immune to the thoughts and feelings. They are a part of being human. Instead, it helps us to respond with resilience. 

So what helped me through it? Returning to my ‘why’. Each and every time I felt vulnerable I reminded myself why I was doing all this in the first place. That helped me to remember that my life’s purpose is not to avoid the judgment and criticism of other people. 

In reality, there will always be someone out there who dislikes, disagrees, or criticises us, no matter what we do. It’s unavoidable. To be resilient to it, we must act in line with our own values and do our best to have a positive impact on the world. 

So when you feel that familiar feeling of vulnerability, come back to your values. Be the person that you wish there were more of in the world 

Thank you again to everyone I am so grateful to you all.

Happy Tuesday everyone

Follow for daily insights from therapy. 

Thoughts can cause so much distress. The power of any thought is in how much we buy into it as meaningful truth or fact. 

So if your thoughts are causing you distress, it makes sense to check out just how much we should believe in the thought. We can do this with a few different methods:

1. Thought challenging: this is where you put the thought to the test. List out the evidence for and against that thought being fact. Sometimes this can be enough to loosen off your belief in a thought that may have been biased. If this process leads to internal arguments with yourself about whether a thought is fact, then try the next method.

2. Practice being mindful of the thoughts. Observe them rather than getting caught up in it. Notice it’s effect on you. View it as an experience washing over you, rather than a part of you. Acknowledge that this is one version of reality, one idea, one theory. Then come back to the here and now. If doing this is difficult it can be helpful to write the thoughts down. This is called thought defusion, which means getting instuck from a thought so that it has less power of you and your actions. 

If you find these difficult to do alone you can get a therapist to support you.

The most natural response to painful emotion is to pull away, block it out and avoid. But that is what keeps us stuck in the long term. Allowing emotion to be present, even welcoming the experience, allows it to wash over you and take its natural course. It will peak like a wave and come back down. It is not easy and can be painful, but leaves us free in the long term.

Follow me for free daily videos  Catastrophising is a common thought bias. When the fight or flight response is triggered, you may not be aware of what has triggered it. That is when your brain searches for the danger that made you feel unsafe. It scans the environment and combines this with imagination to come up with a list of the worst things that could happen. In truly dangerous situations that helps us to survive. In other situations, it just makes anxiety worse.

There is a common misconception that practicing mindfulness means focusing on one thing and blocking out all other thoughts. That leads people to feel frustrated, as if they are not getting it right.
In a mindfulness practice we actually allow thoughts to arrive. But instead of grabbing hold of them, we just observe them as they pass by, gently guiding our attention back to the present moment.
#mindfulness #mindfulnessmeditation

Follow me for more. It’s natural to want to feel liked by the people in your life. But when the need for everyone else’s approval takes over your decision making, it’s time for a re-think.
Something I have discovered in my work and studies is that seeking your own approval first can make it much easier to deal with disapproval from others. By this, I mean that you can make your life choices, big and small, based on your own core values. You work out what is most important for you and try your best to live in line with that. Here’s a little taster of a guided meditation. If you are interested in meditation I have a ten minute version on my youtube for you.

Many people feel frustrated by meditation when they think they need to block out other thoughts. Instead of trying to block anything, allow thoughts and feelings to arrive, and let them pass again, bringing your attention back to the present. Each time you do this, you build on your ability to choose which thoughts you spend time with and which ones you let pass. An incredibly powerful skill for optimal mental health.

For anyone trying to kick some bad habits and replace them with new, healthier ones here is a fascinating finding from the research.
If you can repeat a behaviour for, on average, approximately 66 days, your brain responds by creating the neural connections required for that behaviour to become more habitual and automatic.
So, if you tend to start something and give up a few weeks in, remind yourself of this and keep going. You won’t always feel like it, but put in the work and keep going. .
.
.
.
.

Trauma can be such a difficult concept to understand. Here is a short version of how I sometimes explain it in therapy. What are your thoughts? 
It can be frightening to even consider psychological therapy for PTSD because it asks you to do the thing you most fear - think about it and talk about it. But no therapist would ask you to face overwhelming pain without first gearing you up with emotion coping skills to help you manage it safely. The right therapy at the right time can be life changing.

Everybody has moments when they feel overwhelmed. When there is too much to do. When you don’t believe you can keep up with everyone’s expectations of you. Or when life throws you a curve ball and you feel floored. Those moments are all a normal part of being human.
The thought biases that hit us in these moments are also a normal part of being human. But they are biases, which means they may not always be a true reflection of reality. 
We can’t stop those thought biases from arriving but we can change our response to them. With practice, we can learn to notice biases when they occur and label them as such. Simply recognising and labelling a type of thought pattern helps to take some of the power out of it.

#overwhelmed #stressrelief

Follow me for free daily videos  Overthinking is a normal part of being human. It happens more of the time when we are under stress. I explain why in this video.
To begin tackling overthinking we first need to learn the skill of stepping back from those thoughts and observing them as an experience, rather than getting swept away with them. Thinking about, and noticing patterns in your thoughts is called metacognition. Your thoughts about your thoughts. When we learn to step back from thoughts we are then in a more powerful position to be able to choose which thoughts we spend more time with and which ones we let go.
.
.

Avoidance makes anxiety worse in the long term. When working on anxiety in therapy we teach skills to manage the intensity of the emotion and then we start exposing ourselves to the object of fear. Using the skills to help tolerate the discomfort we stay with the feeling until our body habituates and calms over time. Do this repeatedly and the anxiety response will reduce over time.
.
.
.

Feeling lost at points in our lives is a normal part of the human experience. Many people worry about how they are going to define themselves, what goals they will achieve and how that will look to others. Getting clarity on your values is much more helpful. There are lots of great values exercises that can help us do this. They involve re-evaluating what is most important to us in the various areas of life. Values are different from goals because they have no end point. They are paths we try to stay close to along the way. For more on this, let me know in the comments.

So did you notice that it took more time and conscious effort to name the colour when it did not match the word? If you did then this is know as the Stroop effect.

This short clip comes from the longer Stroop test that was originally designed by John Stroop in 1935. 
It was taught as one of the classic psychology experiments back in my undergraduate days and I’m sharing it with you as just one example of how amazing your brain is.

So what is happening? The Stroop effect demonstrates something called cognitive interference. You experience a delayed reaction because the information about the colour of the print and the word does not match up. 
How is this useful? This test can be combined with others to measure a person’s selective attention capacity and their processing speed ability. 
Here are two theories about why it happens:
The theory of automaticity suggests that recognising and labelling colours is not an automatic process so it takes time and conscious effort (maybe because you don’t often need to do this). The brain automatically understands the meaning of words because it is so well practiced at it.

Another theory is selective attention theory. This suggests that colour recognition requires more attention than reading a word, so it takes longer.

A little message for those ‘can’t be bothered’ days. We all get them. But, when you need to get going, how do overcome that feeling? One part of the equation is choosing carefully which thoughts you give your attention to.
We can’t stop the ‘can’t be bothered’ thoughts from popping into our heads. But we can choose whether to spend time ruminating on them or not.
To call a stop to the rumination, start moving, even in the face of that feeling. Just start moving. Take a shower, get dressed, start engaging in something that you enjoy and requires you to move your body. This alone can turn the mind away from those thoughts that could otherwise give us the urge to stay in bed..
.
.
.

This is a fascinating piece of research. I made this video long before the pandemic hit but I feel it is still relevant. In hard times, it is more important than ever to make careful choices about the thoughts we spend time with. We do not have to spend time with optimistic thoughts if we don’t believe in them. But spending too much time with negative thoughts is hugely damaging. Instead, when under strain, it makes sense to use neutral thinking. This means focusing on what is, and focusing on the next right move. Your mental health will thank you for it.
.
.
.
.

We carry an underlying fear of being exposed as a fraud because shame tells us that we achieved our accomplishments by luck. This video describes 3 factors that contribute to imposter syndrome. When we fall in love we become excited, obsessive and even euphoric. But research shows that the things that make us feel attracted to someone (physical attraction being the most significant early factor) is not the same thing that makes relationships last. Lasting relationships are more influenced by personality, shared values and friendship. Maybe this an insight into why such a big proportion of relationships end.

We all hold some core beliefs about who we are, our place in the world, what to expect from others and the world around us. These beliefs are developed early in life through the experiences we have. Our brains pay close attention to any information that reconfirmed those beliefs, even when the beliefs are damaging. This is because it is more psychologically threatening to have our core beliefs about the world shaken because they give us a template through which we can understand our lives. For example, someone with a core belief that they are unloveable and can expect rejection from others may be highly sensitive to criticism from others or any signs of potential rejection. But beginning a relationship with someone who wants a close relationship can then feel confusing because they expect to experience rejection. Building awareness of our own core beliefs and the influence this has on us can help us to begin the process of positive change and free us from the vicious cycles we get stuck in.
.
.
.

Bit of fun for isolation. How many passes did you count? See below
.
.
.
If you got 13 you were correct. But did you notice the bear moonwalking really badly? 

This is a test of selective attention. The original experiment was conducted by Christopher Chabris and Daniel Simons. They demonstrated that our minds don’t really work the way we think they do. 
Attention is a limited resource and so our mind acts like a spotlight. It zooms in on a task and tunes out other details that don’t appear relevant. So our choices about what we focus on have a significant impact on how we perceive the world. If we spend so much of our time focusing on things that make us feel terrible, we can miss the other things that could change how we feel about life. .
.
.

Abusive relationships can be confusing. It can be hard to work out when a partner’s behaviour has gone too far. Any question marks in your mind are a good enough reason to seek help and support to work things out. Don’t suffer in silence. Help can come in many forms. A trusted friend or family member, a therapist or GP, a teacher.
.

What is it like at a first therapy appointment? It’s normal to feel anxious before you meet your therapist for the first time. Many people worry that they won’t have time to cover everything. Others believe they need to talk about everything in order. It is quite normal for that first appointment to feel like an outpouring of emotion and memories. It is the therapist’s job to work with you over time to unravel it so that together you can make sense of it all. The idea of therapy feels scary at first, but very quickly it becomes a safe place to express yourself and start making positive changes.
.
.
.

Thought biases are normal. Something we all experience. But it happens more when we are already feeling anxious. In turn, they make anxiety worse. Personalising is a common thought bias. When you notice it, label that thought for what it is. A bias, rather than a fact. This helps to take the power out of it.
.
.

??? Sensing the disapproval of others is a powerful force in our decision making and the behaviours we engage in every day. The liberation that comes with the decision to focus only on your own approval of you can be life changing.
.

Our bodies have an inbuilt mechanism for stress resilience. It is human connection. When we connect with others the physiological impact on the body is less damaging than when we deal with it alone. Let’s use all our wonderful technology to help us through the stresses that we face.
.

Today is apparently Blue Monday. Blue Monday is the name given to a day in January claimed to be the most depressing day of the year. The date is generally reported as falling on the third Monday in January. Apparently many factors indicate this including weather conditions, debt level (the difference between debt accumulated, time since Christmas, time since failing our new year’s resolutions, low motivational levels and feeling of a need to take action. #bluemonday #mentalhealth #depression #selfhelp #therapist #therapy #psychologist #depressed #selfcare

4 signs of self-sabotage to look out for. We do this in lots of small ways throughout the day. these add up and change how we feel about ourselves. Awareness is the first step toward change so look out for these today. 
#selfsabotage #selfcare #loveyourself #mentalhealth #mentalhealthadvocate #mentalhealthisimportant  #mentalhealthawarness #mentalhealthsupport #mentalhealth #mentalhealthmatters #mentalhealthblogger #mentalhealthawareness #mentalhealthrecovery #mentalhealthstigma  #mentalhealthhelp

Thought bias 1 – The mental filter

The mental filter. This is a common thought pattern (or style of thinking) when you feel low in mood or suffer with depression or anxiety (or any other mental health problem). We all think this way more of the time when we are stressed, upset, or generally overwhelmed.

Thought bias 2 – Jumping to conclusions

Jumping to conclusions. This is a biased style of thinking that we all do. But we do it more when we are stressed, depressed, anxious and overwhelmed.

Thought bias 3 – Personalising

Personalising is something we all do. But when it happens, it makes you feel worse.

Thought bias 4 – All or nothing thinking

All or nothing thinking, also termed black and white thinking. This is a biased style of thinking that we all do. But we do it more when we are stressed, depressed, anxious and overwhelmed.

Thought bias 5 – Catastrophising

Understand your thoughts. Catastrophising, a thought pattern that we all do. But we do it more when we are stressed, depressed, anxious and overwhelmed. I show you how to spot it keep it in check so that it doesn’t make you feel worse.

Thought bias 6 – Labelling

Labelling is a common thought pattern that is biased and, if left unchecked, makes you feel worse.

Labelling is something that we all do. But we do it more when we are stressed, depressed, anxious and overwhelmed.

Thought bias 7 – Toxic shoulds and musts

Watch out for toxic shoulds and musts and do things for you not just because others want you too.

Whether it be a romantic relationship, friendship, colleagues or even social media profiles, we can listen to our emotions and notice the impact they have on us. If a person, profile or job makes us feel consistently unhappy, it makes sense to look at our part in that unhappiness. In some cases, it may be something to work on, in others, it may be about choosing to walk away. Stop following the social media profiles that trigger insecurities, leave that job that you have hated for years. Making decisions like these for ourselves are not always easy, but can be just what we needed. An example from my life is the simple choice to stop watching the news in the morning. Filling the mind with sensational bad news headlines every morning adds nothing positive to my day. Cutting it out has been an easy way to make a positive difference to my day. A small act of self-compassion. What ways have you stopped going to the circus? #relationships
#mentalhealth #healthyboundaries #selfhealing #selfcare #depression #selfcompassion #positivevibes #anxiety #clinicalpsychology #therapist #therapy

Thoughts are not facts. They are influenced and biased by our emotions. Here’s what you can do about it. Please share this with someone who might need it.
Even if someone has bigger problems you still deserve help with yours. If you think you need help, find yourself a therapist, or psychologist. Get yourself the help you need.

What is Self-soothing?

Self-soothing is a skill used to manage overwhelming emotion. It’s the skill of committing to treating ourselves with kindness and compassion when we are in the midst of struggle. It is choosing behaviours that will help to soothe the body and mind as our distress washes over.

Importantly, self-soothing is not behaviours that block out the emotion. So drugs, alcohol, and suppression are not on the menu. Instead, we want to look after ourselves while the emotion passes naturally. To do this, we can use all the senses:

Sight
This may be photographs of loved ones or a favourite holiday. Alternatively it could be a movie or piece of artwork that makes you feel uplifted. Walking in nature and observing your surroundings can work too.

Sound

Music, singing, the sound of water. Sound is a powerful tool for changing how you feel. Make your own self-soothing playlist with all your best picks for feeling calm and soothed.

Touch

This can be comforting textures like a super soft blanket, a favourite pillow or cuddly toy. It could also be a warm cuddle with a loved one. Human touch is a personal one but very powerful if it works for you.

Taste

Slowly and mindfully savouring a favourite treat can help us to feel soothed (if eating is not part a safety behaviour for you). Strong mints can provide an anchor when we want to be mindful and stay present.

Smell

Sense of smell is actually the quickest way to calm the body. So if you like lavender or have a scent that you associate with comfort and safeness, keep some with you. Breathing in that scent is going to help you feel safe and calm very quickly.

Some of these you may use already, others might take some time to feel effective. So pick one or two and put in some practice. It is the intention of committing to take care of yourself that is key. Once you find the ones that work best for you, make sure you can access them when you might need it.

You can do this by setting up a self-soothing box. Take a shoe box and fill it with lots of things that you find soothing.

Read more at www.doctorjuliesmith.com

V University: class #6  @millennial.therapist breaks down 3 relationship truths we don’t necessarily want to hear! I found this perspective so valuable whether you apply it to familial relationships, friendships, or a romantic partner. ?
?
To summarize:?
1. Sometimes we *do* ask for too much – we may ask them to fulfill all our needs.?
2. Sometimes we’re asking the wrong person to fulfill our needs. It may require reevaluating the relationship to find equilibrium. ?
3. Sometimes we get in our own way. We need to be self-aware of our own insecurities, and actively work to make sure they don’t negatively impact our ability to build healthy relationships. ?
?
#VUniversity #TheArtofBeingHuman #communicationtips #problemsolving?
?
Note: Sara is an existential psychotherapist, consultant, writer, and columnist for USA Today. You can learn more about her and see her work at http://sara-kuburic.com!

V University: class #8  Our inner critic is ever-present but it tends to be louder when we’re less aware or avoidant of what it’s *really* trying to tell us. @millennial.therapist explains how we can understand our inner critic better – and how to show ourselves grace and take back control ???
?
1. The first step is awareness! Observe your inner critic – what is it saying and when does it show up? ?
2. Pause and apologize. Remember to show yourself the kindness you would show others. ?
3. Think about what emotions and truths might be hiding behind your inner critic. ?
4. Try to rephrase! It’s not about toxic positivity, but rather about reassuring yourself and changing your perspective. ?
?
#VUniversity #TheArtofBeingHuman #selfsabotage #selfawareness ?
?

V University: class 9??? ?@millennial.therapist helps us reflect on some common mistakes we make when trying to help the people we love, even when we have the best of intentions. ?
?
To summarize: ?
1. We try to *save* people rather than support them. This can be disempowering for the person you’re trying to help. ?
2. We often refocus on ourselves. Though our intentions may be good, sometimes sharing our own experiences can take away from our active listening and support role. ?
?
#VUniversity #TheArtofBeingHuman #selfsabotage #selfawareness ?

V University: class #4 ? One question I grappled with when I was younger was, “why am I taking everything so personally?” The reaction is often an emotional one and sometimes those reactions are not grounded in reality. More often than not, it has nothing to do with us at all but rather it reflect the other person’s experience or reality.

To summarize:
 when you’re unsure of who you are, you’re less confident. and when you’re less confident, other people’s behaviour impacts you more.
 we’re more self-centered when we’re younger – we forget that people have their own lives and we focus only on ourselves.
 In our 30s onwards, we’re more likely to act as “gatekeepers” — choosing more deliberately what we allow in, and what we can acknowledge as someone projecting.

#VUniversity #TheArtofBeingHuman #20s #30s

Class #2 of V University Semester 2 ft. @millennial.therapist  In this episode, Sara breaks down why, as humans, we often want what we can’t (or don’t) have. ?
?
An entire NOVEL could probably be written on this topic – maybe it has been already  – but this is a quick summary of the most common reasons we may behave this way. ?
?
1. We may lack a sense of excitement in our lives, and therefore we enjoy chasing something inaccessible. ?
2. We may romanticize what we don’t know. Our desires can feel perpetually better than what we have in front of us. The whole “grass is greener” mentality. ?
3. We may have grown up not having our needs met, so it feels familiar to want the things we can’t have.?
4. It’s safer to want the things we can’t have because then we never have to grapple with getting them. ?
?
Do any of the above reasons resonate with you? For me, #2 and #4 hit home. ?
?
#VUniversity #TheArtofBeingHuman

 @ericnam @sarahbarrios

Okay, first, this was really hard to film because we’re really nice people  but, for the sake of breaking down cognitive distortions we put in the hard work. 
So…hands up if you’ve ever heard that critical voice before. 
Not everything you think is true. In fact, that critical voice likely didn’t start with you.
We are meaning making machines. It’s so easy to jump to the worst case scenario that supports your fears, insecurities, and wounds. That internal system really likes to look for evidence that supports your pain. So beware. Be careful of the meaning you attribute. And for now, notice. Notice your thoughts and see if you can take a beat. 
X Vienna and Sara
